taxonomicNotes:
Six or seven subspecies are widely recognised: Melanochelys trijuga trijuga (Schweigger, 1812); M. t. coronata (Anderson, 1879); M. t. edeniana (Theobald, 1876); M. t. indopeninsularis (Annandale ,1913); M. t. parkeri (Deraniyagala, 1939); M. t. thermalis (Lesson, 1830). Subspecies wiroti (Reimann in Nutaphand, 1979) was synonymized with M. t. edeniana. The colour and size is considered as criteria for subspecies differentiation (Deraniyagala 1939, Das 1995, Das and Bhupathy 2009). The head of M. trijuga thermalis is highly ornamented with either red, orange, or yellow spots or blotches. During a study of 76 live M. t. thermalis from 19 different localities in Sri Lanka a high percentage (76.%) of specimens had orange, red, yellow and brown patches on the head. Head ornamentation was common and distinct in young (Abeysekera et al. 2015).

There are many Sinhala names for the species which vary according to the province. However, the widely used name is the Gal Ibbā, (= rock terrapin). The others are Goo Ibbā (= ordure terrapin), Diya kukula (= water fowl), Thumba Ibbā (= small terrapin), valan Ibbā (= pot terrapin) and mada kakkutta (= mud crab). In Tamil it is known as Karuppu Amai (= Black terrapin), Kal amai (= rock terrapin), Pee amai (= ordure terrapin), Tanni amai (= water terrapin).
Generally considered to consist of at least two morphologically distinguishable lineages.

The nominate subspecies Phrynocephalus mystaceus mystaceus is found in Europe, ranging as far east as the Volga River sands inclusive. 
Wide mtDNA sampling of this species across its range suggests that two deeply divergent clades exist, one isolated in the Khorasan region of northeastern Iran and the other in the remainder of its Middle Asian range, a pattern previously found with more limited sampling using other genetic markers (Solovyeva et al. 2018). Solovyeva et al. (2018) "tentatively" elect to describe the Khorasan lineage as a subspecies, P. m. khorasanus, rather than a full species due to weak morphological differentiation from populations elsewhere and the existence of both morphologically and genetically intermediate populations in the Caspian and Middle Asian regions. At the same time, this work found that the two previously recognized subspecies - P. m. galli and P. m. aurantiacocaudatus - are not supported by either mtDNA or morphological data. Solovyeva et al. (2020) consequently synonymized them with the nominate form, while recommending further research to clarify the claimed morphological distinctiveness of the latter (based on characters they were unable to examine in preserved material).

Six genetically and geographically distinct lineages have been identified in Natrix tessellata, and some or all of these may warrant specific recognition following further research (Guiking et al. 2004).

There are six recognized subspecies: Eremias arguta arguta (Pallas, 1773) is distributed in Kazakhstan; E a. deserti (Gmelin, 1789) is found in the west of the species range from the Ural River in the west to the eastern parts of the North Caucasus in the southwest (this subspecies is present in Romania, Moldova and Ukraine); E. a. transcaucasica Darevsky, 1953 inhabits eastern parts of Transcaucasia; E. a. uzbekistanica Chernov, 1934 is present in Uzbekistan and the frontier regions of Turkmenistan, southern Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan; E. a. darevskii Tsaruk, 1986 is restricted to the Issyk Kul Depression in Kyrgyzstan; E. a. potanini Bedrjaga, 1912 is found in the area adjacent to Balkhash Lake and the Zaisan Depression in Kazakhstan. mtDNA results provide no justification for recognizing this latter form as distinct, and Poyarkov et al. (2014) indicate that this should be considered a junior synonym of the nominate subspecies. An unnamed form within from the Ili River Valley has been found to be distinct both genetically and morphologically (Orlova et al. 2012, Poyarkov et al. 2014), being sister to all other E. arguta, and may represent an undescribed species (Poyarkov et al. 2014).

This species exhibits close similarities to Eryx tataricus, and the two are difficult to distinguish (Ezkandarzadeh et al. 2013). Ezkandarzadeh et al. (2013) attribute records of E. tataricus from Khorasan Province in northeastern Iran to E. miliaris (also see Mohammad et al. 2017). The distribution of the two taxa elsewhere is in need of clarification: Zhao and Adler (1993) provide a "composite range" for the complex in China as the separate ranges of the two taxa in this country cannot be identified. Ezkandarzadeh et al. (2013) outline the distribution of both species and report both from Mongolia, however Zhao and Adler (1993) and Terbish et al. (2006) consider that only E. tataricus occurs in this country. Cryptic species may exist within the E. miliaris-tataricus complex, based on the finding by Ezkandarzadeh et al. (2013) that two Iranian specimens (to which they applied the name Eryx cf. miliaris) could not confidently be referred to this taxon. In the northwestern (Russian) part of its range, the subspecies E. m. nogaiorum is recognized; however recent phylogenetic research implies that this population must be considered invalid (Eskandarzadeh et al. 2020).  The same study suggests that E. tataricus represents a junior synonym of E. miliaris (Eskandarzadeh et al. 2020), but this account retains it as valid pending further research to confirm this assignment given the complex taxonomic history of these names and the need for wider sampling outside Iran.
The validity of subspecies described from western Siberia and the Altai region, E. d. niger Golubeva, 1923 and E. d. tenebrosa Sobolevsky, 1929, is disputed.
This species is included in Hemorrhois, rather than Coluber, following Nagy et al. (2004). It appears to be paraphyletic (Schätti and Utiger 2001).

Records of this species from Pakistan, reported at least as recently as Khan (1999), refer to Eremias persica, previously a subspecies of E. velox (Baig and Masroor 2006). Four subspecies are presently recognized, E. v. borkini, E. v. caucasica and E. v. roborowskii in addition to the nominate form.

Two subspecies are recognised: Cuora mouhoutii mouhotii (Gray, 1863) and C. m. obsti (Fritz, Andreas & Lehr, 1997).

Traditionally placed in the monotypic genus Pyxidea until Honda et al. (2002) demonstrated that mouhotii is genetically nested inside Cuora. Hybrids of C. mouhotii with Cuora galbinifrons or C. bourreti gave rise to specimens that were erroneously described as a separate species, Cuora serrata.

Included with Cyclemys dentata until very recently. Previously considered to contain just a single, variable species, Cyclemys remains subject to ongoing taxonomic investigations which rearrange the taxonomy and nomenclature on an ongoing basis. Key references: Fritz et al. 1996, 1997; Iverson and McCord 1997; Guicking et al. 2002.

Varanus irrawadicus Yang & Li, 1987 and V. vietnamensis Yang & Liu, 1994 were previously described as nominal species, but both were synonymized with V. bengalensis by Böhme and Ziegler (1997). The same authors raised V. bengalensis nebulosus (Gray, 1831) to full species status based on a V. b. bengalensis specimen obtained from a market in Phuket (exhibiting characters within the range of V. b. nebulosus), which was thought to prove sympatry between the two forms, together with differences in hemipenial structure. It is widely accepted that this specimen instead represents a geographic race of V. bengalensis, based on a very detailed study of geographic variation in V. bengalensis across its range (Auffenberg 1994). The Phuket locality is also considered doubtful, as this is an extensively-visited area where no nebulosus-morph monitors have otherwise been recorded, and the specimen recorded in the market may have been collected further north (D. Bennett pers. comm. 2017). Consequently V. nebulosus is treated here as a junior synonym of V. bengalensis.

Macey et al. (2005) conducted a phylogenetic analysis of the genus Teratoscincus and concluded on genetic grounds that T. keyserlingi (until then regarded as a subspecies of T. scincus) should be considered a valid species. This author did not, however, conduct any morphological work to determine whether the proposed arrangement represented a morphologically diagnosable species (P. Uetz pers. comm. 2013). Subsequently Wagner et al. (2016) noted that most Afghan records of this species appear to be referable to T. keyserlingi. These authors note that the assignment of Afghan records to the two taxa is "complicated", although they recognize both as distinct species occurring in Afghanistan. Nazarov et al. (2017) subsequently elevated the isolated Fergana Valley form T. s. rustamowi to specific status based on both molecular and morphological methods and clarified range limits within Teratoscincus as presently understood.

This species exhibits close similarities to Eryx miliaris, and the two are difficult to distinguish (Ezkandarzadeh et al. 2013). Ezkandarzadeh et al. (2013) attribute records of E. tataricus from Khorasan Province in northeastern Iran to E. miliaris. The distribution of the two taxa elsewhere is in need of clarification: Zhao and Adler (1993) provide a "composite range" for the complex in China as the separate ranges of the two taxa in this country cannot be identified. Ezkandarzadeh et al. (2013) outline the distribution of both species and report both from Mongolia, however, Zhao and Adler (1993) and Terbish et al. (2006) consider that only E. tataricus occurs in this country. Cryptic species may exist within the E. miliaris-tataricus complex, based on the finding by Ezkandarzadeh et al. (2013) that two Iranian specimens (to which they applied the name Eryx cf. miliaris) could not confidently be referred to this taxon. The subspecies Eryx tataricus vittatus is sometimes treated as a distinct species following Tokar (1989), a scheme followed widely in Russian literature, however the distinctness of this taxon was not supported by Kluge (1993 using a different set of osteological characters. Given the problematic taxonomy of the miliaris-tataricus complex as a whole and the low degree of both morphological and genetic differentiation between these taxa (Pyron et al. 2014, Ezkandarzadeh et al. 2013) it is retained here as a subspecies pending a revision of the group as a whole. This follows the recommendation by Reynolds et al. (2014), who identified E. t. vittatus as a diagnosable taxon but noted the lack of clarity regarding the distributions of all three taxa (E. tataricus, E. miliaris, and E. t. vitttaus). New phylogenetic research suggests that E. tataricus represents a junior synonym of E. miliaris (Eskandarzadeh et al. 2020), but this account retains it as valid pending further research to confirm this assignment given the complex taxonomic history of these names and the need for wider sampling outside Iran.

The taxon Trapelus sanguinolentus is variously considered a distinct species or a subspecies of T. agilis (the latter scheme following Rastegar-Pouyani 1998). Macey and Ananjeva (2004) found that the two taxa were genetically distinct. This account treats T. sanguinolentus as a full species following Melville et al. (2009) and Wagner et al. (2011), although Shahamat et al. (2020) found that this arrangement renders T. agilis paraphyletic based on mtDNA.
In Central Asia this form has sometimes been known as T. s. aralensis, although this subspecific division has been controversial (Macey and Ananjeva 2004). Macey and Ananjeva (2004) investigated allozyme variation within the two lineages of T. sanguinolentus, and found very little evidence of genetic variation. On this basis, T. s. aralensis should be considered a junior synonym of T. s. sanguinolentus (Macey and Ananjeva 2004).
The conservation assessment of this taxon is complicated by the conviction that the current taxonomic designation hides a complex of several different species.

Hemidactylus brookii was described by Gray, 1845 based on specimens collected from Borneo (Smith 1935). The traditional species concept for H. brookii is a very widespread, pantropical lizard, and its taxonomic history is confused (Bauer et al. 2010; see this paper and Mahony 2011 for a taxonomic discussion). New World members of this lineage were elevated to species status (as H. haitianus and H. leightoni) by Powell et al. (1996); H. haitanus has also been confirmed as the lineage represented on Bioko Island, Equatorial Guinea (Carranza and Arnold 2006), implying that this species likely represents a historical introduction to the West Indies. H. haitianus and H. leightoni have subsequently been synonymized within H. angulatus (Rösler and Glaw 2010). Carranza and Arnold (2006) elevated African H. angulatus, previously a subspecies of H. brookii, to specific status, confining H. brookii to Asia, and confirmed that H. angulatus, H. leightoni and H. haitianus are only distantly-related to H. brookii. Bauer et al. (2010) examined the taxonomic status of Asian forms and raised the taxon parvimaculatus Deraniyagala, 1953 to specific status, reporting it from south of Palghat Gap in India, and from Sri Lanka. This is probably also the form that occurs in the Comoros and Mascarene Islands based on genetic similarity to Sri Lankan populations (Rocha et al. 2005, Bauer et al. 2010) (although work in press suggests that some of these presumed H. parvimaculatus may be referrable to H. malcolmsmithi - A. Bauer pers. comm. 2019).

Rösler and Glaw (2010) subsequently removed the Indonesian H. tenkatei from synonymy with H. brookii on morphological grounds. Mahony (2011) synonymized the Burmese form H. subtriedroides, treated as a synonym of H. brookii by Bauer et al. (2010), with H. tenkatei. This action was subsequently disputed by Kathriner et al. (2014), but the status of H. subtriedroides remains unresolved (Lajmi et al. 2016). Following Zug et al. (2007) the Indian population previously treated as H. mahendrai is included in the synonymy of H. brookii by Bauer et al. (2010) and (provisionally, pending examination of type material) by Mahony (2011). The distributions of H. brookii and H. parvimaculatus in India remain unclear. A comprehensive review of all Indian taxa presently included within H. brookii is urgently required (Bauer et al. 2011).

Following this complex series of taxonomic changes, Mahony (2011) reexamined type specimens of H. brookii and redescribed this species based on two of the three syntypes (the third being found by these authors' examination to represent H. tenkatei). On nomenclatural grounds, Mahony (2011) retained Gecko tytleri within the synonymy of H. brookii. This author also tentatively retained H. murrayi from Gujurat as a junior synonym of H. brookii in the absence of comparative material to confirm its specific identity, but noted that based on the original description it is "very unlikely to be conspecific with H. brookii s.s.". He also provisionally included H. luzonensis (considered a probable junior synonym of H. tenkatei by Rösler and Glaw 2010) within the synonymy of H. brookii until Philippine specimens can be examined to verify their identity. Two remaining names previously treated as synonyms of H. brookii, H. gleadowi and H. kushmorensis, were resurrected for Pakistani members of the brookii complex found to represent distinct species (Mahony 2011).

Lajmi et al. (2016) conducted a combined morphological and molecular analysis of the H. brookii complex sensu lato, focusing particularly on delimiting species in India. These results suggest that 5-7 major clades exist within the complex, five of which appear to correspond to species described or resurrected in the above-described studies, and one of which contains five described species. The authors resurrect the name H. murrayi for the remaining clade based on comparison with material from the Gujurat type locality; they propose that this may be a senior synonym for the taxon described by Rösler and Glaw (2010) as H. tentakei. Their sequence data and comparison with Bornean material of H. brookii suggests that this name is likely to be applicable to the form widespread through mainland Southeast Asia, and that Bauer et al. (2010) were in error to consider this taxon conspecific with the Borneo type series. This account provisionally retains the name H. brookii for this taxon, as the Indian study did not conduct morphological analysis of Southeast Asian records to confirm their identity. Uetz (2017) noted that the status of H. murrayi is uncertain as the type series has been lost.

Jiang and Zhao (1983) described a subspecies R. n. pentasupralabialis for the specimens from Sichuan and Yunnan, China. Subsequently, based on a morphological comparison, Zhao (1995) give a specific rank for this taxon, as R. pentasupralabialis. Therefore R. nuchalis is a monotypic species now.
Because of the wide distribution of this species, many herpetologists believe that this is a species complex Das 2002).

This species has four subspecies:
P. jerdonii jerdonii (Günther, 1875)
P. jerdonii bourreti (Klemmer, 1963) - Bourret's Pitviper
P. jerdonii meridionalis (Bourret, 1935)
P. jerdonii xanthomelas (Günther, 1889) - Red Spotted Pitviper.
Cryptelytrops insularis was split from C. albolabris (Malhotra & Thorpe 2004).

This species has been recently placed in the genus Ophites. Three subspecies are recognized: L. s. subcinctus, L. s. maculatus, and L. s. sealei. It is possible that the subspecies on Palawan Island (Lycodon subcinctus sealei Leviton, 1955) is an island endemic, however, this needs to be confirmed as Lanza (1999) reported a specimen from Western Sarawak, Malaysia and suggested that the species may have been accidentally introduced to the Philippines.

This taxon was originally described as Trimeresurus xiangchengensis by Zhao et al. (1978), however, more recently it has been assigned to the genus of Protobothrops (Guo et al.2006). There has been much debate over the validity of this species. McDiarmid et al. (1999) suggested that it may be a synonym of Protobothrops mucrosquamatus, but Guo et al. (2009) concluded that it is a valid species and this arrangement is followed here.

This species was previously described as Odorrana chapaensis by Ngo et al. 2006 and Che et al. 2007, Amolops chapaensis by Bain and Nguyen, 2004 and Rana sp. ‘‘Cao Bang’’ (ROM 26476) by Chen et al. 2005.

Coelognathus radiatus was described by Boie in 1827 as Coluber radiatus based on specimens collected from Java, Indonesia. Dr. Patrick Russell's work "Indian Serpentes" published in 1801 also has drawings of this taxa (Smith 1943). This species has been long included under the genus Elaphe (Smith 1943), but following Helfenberger (2001) and Utiger et al. (2005), the Oriental Ratsnakes have been assigned to the genus Coelognathus.

Following revision of Trimeresurus by Malhotra and Thorpe (2004), the generic identity of this species remains to be clarified. David et al. (2011) exclude this species from their arrangement of Trimeresurus sensu lato, and suggest that it is likely to warrant a new genus (in their scheme, subgenus).
The taxonomic status of this species should be verified with reference to the original description.
Three subspecies are recognized: Pseudoxenodon m. macrops, P. m. fukienensis, and P. m. sinensis.
Oligodon eberhardti has been confused with O. catenatus.

Takeuchi et al. (2012) examined genetic relationships between Rhabdophis t. tigrinus from Japan, R. t. formosanus from Taiwan, and populations on the Asian mainland (sometimes recognized as the distinct subspecies R. t. lateralis, although the validity of this form has been disputed - see Takeuchi et al. 2012 for a discussion). On the basis of their results, these authors proposed specific status for R. t. formosanus and R. t. lateralis. Takeuchi et al. (2012) sequenced R. t. lateralis (which occurs throughout China and the Korean Peninsula, and in far eastern Russia) only from South Korea, and acknowledge the absence of known morphological characters that can distinguish this taxon from R. t. tigrinus. On this basis, and pending genetic comparison with specimens from China that can more fully characterize genetic variation within R. tigrinus, both R. t. lateralis and R. t. formosanus are provisionally retained here as subspecies of R. tigrinus.

Two subspecies have been recognized: Bungarus multicinctus multicinctus and Bungarus multicinctus wanghaotingi. The latter is treated here as a full species following Leviton et al. (2003). It is probable that both members of this species group contain additional cryptic forms (Leviton et al. 2003).

Jiang (2004) indicated that, based on morphological similarities, P. chinensis should be treated as a synonym of P. formosensis. This assignment is not supported by recent genetic research, which found that P. formosensis is not closely-related to P. chinensis and is instead sister to P. hamptoni (Guo et al. 2011).
This species has also been placed in the genera Dendrophis and Ahaetulla.

Nagy et al. (2004) identified that the genus Hierophis as then understood was paraphyletic, and that H. spinalis was closer to Eirenis than to other species of Hierophis. This author's recommendation that H. spinalis be transferred to Eirenis has not, however, been widely adopted, and Kharin (2011) erected the new monotypic genus Orientocoluber for this species.

The Vietnamese island specimens, which have been deposited in a Russian institution, have not recently been examined, and work is needed to confirm their identity (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. August 2011).

The distribution of this species is likely confused with P. macularius in the literature and is probably unreliable. The two species were synonymized by Huang (2004), with P. macularius becoming a subspecies of P. margaritophorus. Vogel (2010) rejected this synonymy on the basis that Huang appears not to have examined and compared type material for the two forms. Recent molecular data reveals high genetic diversity within P. margaritophorus, and further research may justify the treatment of the two forms as separate species (Guo et al. 2011). An additional subspecies, P. m. tamdaoensis, is here retained within P. margaritophorus, although Das (2010) treats this as a separate species.

The validity of the subspecies Elaphe carinata deqenensis has been a source of some dispute (Guo et al. 2012 and refs therein). Based on morphological comparisons and low levels of genetic divergence within E. carinata, Guo et al. (2012) determined that the morphologcal characters used to diagnose the subspecies were unreliable, and provisionally synonymized it with E. c. carinata. These authors cautioned, however, that their genetic data was not sufficient to determine whether E. c. deqenensis is a valid evolutionary unit.

This species was treated as a subspecies of the ubiquitous Dendrelaphis pictus, until it was elevated to full species by Ziegler and Vogel (1999). It is very similar to D. cyanochloris (G. Vogel pers. comm. August 2011). Historical records of D. pictus, D. cyanochloris and D. ngansonensis may be confused, making the true distribution difficult to establish (Q.T. Nguyen and G. Vogel pers. comm. August 2011).
This species was resurrected from synonymy with Lycodon rushstrati by Vogel et al. (2009). The exact distribution of these two species needs further research.

The distinction between Viridovipera gumprechti and the southern Chinese V. yunnanensis is taxonomically complex, and opinions differ on the distribution of the two forms (N. Ananjeva pers. comm. August 2011). Das (2010) opins that V. yunnanensis is the correct name for the species also found in Myanmar (Chin and Kachin States), Laos, and Vietnam outside the Annamite Mountains, but this account follows Nguyen et al. (2009) in assigning these records to V. gumprechti, confining V. yunnanensis to China.
Bungarus fasciatus was described by Schneider in 1801 based on drawings and a description by Dr. Patrick Russell of specimens collected from Bengal, India (Smith 1943).

This species has also been placed in the genus Ophites, but this is not widely accepted. This species is often synonymized with or treated as a subspecies of Lycodon aulicus, but they are here considered as distinct species following Taylor (1965) and David and Vogel (1996).

This snake has been treated as a subspecies of B. multicinctus (e.g. in the Reptile Database - Uetz et al. 2021). It is treated here as a full species following Leviton et al. (2003) and Chen et al. (2021). It is probable that both members of this species group contain additional cryptic forms (Leviton et al. 2003).

The genus Trirhinopholis is a junior synonym of Plagiopholis (see Smith 1943). This species has previously been treated as a synonym of P. nuchalis, but Tillack et al. (2006) provide evidence against this synonymy.
Taxonomic study is required to assess whether populations across this large geographic area are truly conspecific. Two subspecies are recognized, Cylindrophis r. ruffus and C. r. burmanus.
This species has been also recently placed in the genera Elaphe and Rhadinophis.

This species is related to Viridovipera stejnegeri, with which it was formerly confused. The distinction between V. gumprechti and the southern Chinese V. yunnanensis is taxonomically complex, and opinions differ on the distribution of the two forms (N. Ananjeva pers. comm. August 2011). Das (2010) opins that V. yunnanensis is the correct name for the species found in Myanmar (Chin and Kachin States), Laos, and Vietnam outside the Annamite Mountains, but this account follows Nguyen et al. (2009) in assigning these records to V. gumprechti, confining V. yunnanensis to China.
This species was formerly placed in the genus Natrix. Two subspecies are recognized: R. s. subminiatus and R. s. helleri.

This species has long been treated as a subspecies of Fowlea piscator. Literature records of this species and F. piscator, which occur in sympatry (Zug et al. 2006, Vogel and David 2006) are confused. The subspecies F. f. schnurrenbergeri is now recognized as a full species (Vogel and David 2006). Additional study of this species complex is warranted, as additional species may exist under the name F. flavipunctatus.
This species has also been placed in the genus Ophites, but this is not widely accepted.
New genus Viridovipera erected by Malhotra and Thorpe (2004a).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).
Two subspecies are recognized: S. p. percarinata and S. p. suriki.

A phylogenetic analysis of the genus Amphiesma has found it to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species have consequently been assigned to Herpetoreas or Hebius (Guo et al. 2014). The Russian subspecies H. vibakari ruthveni may be elevated to specific status in future.

This snake was originally described as a subspecies of Dinodon rufozonatum, and later transferred to D. flavozonatum by Smith (1943). This assignment has subsequently been shown to be incorrect, and Orlov and Ryabov (2004) elevated this taxon, then treated as a subspecies of D. rufozonatum, to full species level.

Orlov et al. (2002) suggested that this snake should be treated as a synonym of Ovophis monticola convictus (now O. convictus - Malhotra et al. 2011). The specific status of this form has recently been supported on the basis of both morphological and genetic evidence (Malhotra et al. 2011). This revision also extended the distribution of this species in Vietnam as far south as the Da Lat Plateau, and reassigned records from Laos to other species.
Zhao (1995) treated this former subspecies of Ovophis monticola as a valid species, and this assignment has since been supported by Malhotra et al. (2011).
This species was placed in the genus Ophites by Zhao and Adler (1993), but Lycodon is the name in most frequent use for this species and the change has not been widely accepted.

This species was historically placed in the genus Amblycephalus. Recent molecular work supports morphological evidence indicating that this species and Pareas nuchalis form a clade distinct from other Pareas (Guo et al. 2011), and its generic status may therefore warrant revision. Two subspecies are recognized: P. c. carinatus and P. c. unicolor.
This species was previously recognized in the genus Trimeresurus, and Popeia is considered a subgenus of Trimeresurus by some authors (David et al. 2011).

Hemidactylus bowringii was first described as Doryura bowringii by Gray in 1845 based on specimens reportedly collected from Hong Kong or its neighbourhood (Smith 1935). A taxonomic evaluation of the bowringii group in Myanmar and adjacent Yunnan (McMahan and Zug 2007) precipitated a re-evaluation of Indian "H. bowringii", and subsequently these populations were reallocated to Hemidactylus aquilonius by Purkayastha et al. (2010), restricting H. bowringi to China and adjacent areas. McMahan and Zug (2007) proposed a provisional arrangement in which the name Hemidactylus bowringii applies to a taxon found "from eastern Indochina through southern China to Taiwan and the Ryukyus". These authors caution however that several nomenclatural issues remain to be resolved in order to ascertain whether this is the taxon to which the name H. bowringii properly refers. MacMahan and Zug (2007) suggest that the name Hemidactylus berdmorei, presently a junior synonym of H. bowringi, may be available for a taxon from Tanintharyi should this prove to be specifically distinct from H. bowringii group populations in central and northern Myanmar. Subsequent work involving "many weeks of survey" in north-central and southern Tanintharyi has not recorded bowringii group geckos, leading G. Zug (pers. comm. 2018) to conclude that H. berdmorei should be treated as a nomen dubium.

Amarasinghe et al. (2018) designated a neotype for E. multifasciata and examined the taxonomy of names associated with the Eutropis multifasciata group using both molecular and morphological data, and found that the subspecies E. m. balinensis and E. m. tjendikianensis represent junior synonyms of E. multifasciata. This species has long been considered a species complex, and deep divergence between several 16S clades identified by Mulcahy et al. (2018) supports this suggestion.

This widespread gecko may be a species complex (Rösler et al. 2011). Genetic data suggests that this species' occurrence at least in the Lesser Sunda Islands, where it is widespread, is a consequence of human-mediated dispersal, as subpopulations on these islands exhibit no genetic diversity compared with subpopulations from Java (J. McGuire unpubl. data). Rösler et al. (2011) revalidated the name Gekko reevesii for populations from northern Viet Nam and southern China long recognized as being morphologically distinct from, and broadly sympatric with, G. gecko. These authors identified two "relatively deeply divergent evolutionary lineages" within this species, and indicated that deeper sampling of G. gekko from across its range is necessary to resolve the systematics of this group.
This is a split from the broader concept of Ingerophrynus galeatus (Fei et al. 2009).

This was formerly regarded as a subspecies of Ovophis monticola. Malhotra et al. (2011) recommended elevating it to a full species based on genetic research and morphological variation. This account follows that recommendation; however as no formal taxonomic action has been taken to elevate this taxon, its appropriate taxonomic status remains uncertain.

The known specimen of this snake was referred to Dendrelaphis pictus by Karsen et al. (1998), although Lazell and Lu (1990) had previously recognized its distinctiveness. It was formally described as a new species by Lazell (2002). It is similar to D. subocularis, and Lazell (2002) hypothesizes that this may be a relict species that diverged from the common ancestor of this species and D. pictus. Wall (1903) reported D. pictus from Hong Kong; as this specimen has now been lost (Lazell and Lu 1990) it is unclear whether this record is referrable to D. hollinrakei.

Liu et al. (2012) conducted a molecular phylogenetic analysis of this recently-described species and concluded that genetic evidence supports its recognition as a full species by Yang et al. (2011). Further work is required to resolve its relationships with the morphologically similar P. trungkhanensis, which was not included in the genetic analysis (Liu et al. 2012).

The first specimen of this snake to be collected was misidentified as Cryptelytrops albolabris (Zhao 2006, Guo and Wang 2011). The two species are not closely-related. and instead Sinovipera sichuanensis has been recovered as the sister taxon to Cryptelytrops + Viridovipera, prompting Guo and Wang (2011) to erect the new genus Sinovipera.
Zhao (1997) described this species based on specimens from Hainan originally attributed to Rhabdophis chrysargos.
The two known specimens of Typhlops lazelli were originally attributed to the widespread Ramphotyphlops albiceps (Wallach and Pauwels 2004).

Jiang and Zhao (1983) described a subspecies R. nuchalis pentasupralabialis for the specimens from Sichuan and Yunnan, China. Subsequently, based on a morphological comparison, Zhao (1995) give a specific rank for this taxon, as R. pentasupralabialis.

Jiang (2004) indicated that, based on morphological similarities, Pareas chinensis should be treated as a synonym of P. formosensis. This assignment is not supported by recent genetic research, which found that P. formosensis is not closely-related to P. chinensis and is instead sister to P. hamptoni (Guo et al. 2011).

Until recently, this species was included within Daboia russelii, a species understood to have a widespread but heavily disjunct distribution within South and Southeast Asia. The number of recognized subspecies of this wide-ranging snake is variable, but six are traditionally accepted (Thorpe et al. 2007). Morphological analysis suggests, however, that only two distinct forms exist, one (D. r. russelii) restricted to the Indian subcontinent and the other (for which the name with priority is D. r. siamensis)  found in the remainder of the snake's range (Wūster et al. 1992). These authors refrained from elevating D. r. siamensis to a full species due to the lack of molecular research to support this conclusion. More recently, using both molecular and morphological data, Thorpe et al. (2007) found strong support for this division and recognized two distinct species, D. russelii (incorporating the former subspecies D. r. pulchella and D. r. nordicus as well as D. r. russelii) and D. siamensis (incorporating D. r. limitis, D. r. sublimitis and D. r. formosensis). Due to low divergence between members of each lineage, Thorpe et al. (2007) do not recognize distinct subspecies of either form.

Le et al. (2014) concluded that the Yangtze and Red River subpopulations of Rafetus swinhoei do not show significant genetic divergence and do not warrant recognition as separate evolutionary significant units for conservation management. However, it appears that Le et al. (2014) did not actually have any samples from the Yangtze subpopulation, only samples from the Vietnamese and Chinese parts of the Red River catchment. Chen (2015) found two distinct mtDNA lineages of R. swinhoei which are roughly 2.8% divergent from each other (Cytochrome B and NADH dehydrogenase 4), one represented by Red River specimens and the second one by a Shanghai museum specimen of unknown origin. In the meantime, tissue samples from the male of Suzhou Zoo and the female of Changsha Zoo proved to be concordant with the Shanghai museum specimen (H. Chen pers. comm.). This points to a possibility that the Yangtze and the Red River subpopulations may represent separate taxa at least at the level of subspecies. In that case the Yangtze subpopulation would represent the nominate form Rafetus swinhoei swinhoei and the Vietnamese and Chinese Red River subpopulation the subspecies Rafetus swinhoei leloii.

The relationship between this species and Parahelicops annamensis has long been uncertain (David et al. 2015), due to poor knowledge of variation in both taxa. With access to a series of 13 specimens of P. annamensis David et al. 2015 were able to redescribe both species and, based on the results of their analysis, erected the new genus Isanophis containing the single species I. boonsongi.
We follow Frost (2020) in placing this very poorly known but highly distinctive species in the genus Quasipaa. It was previously placed in the genus Yerana.
This species is sometimes assigned to the genus Cryptobranchium.

We follow Matsui et al. (2005) in separating this species from Microhyla ornata. Call properties of this species vary, and it is believed to be a species complex (A. Borzee pers. comm. September 2019).

authority: (Fei, Ye & Huang in Fei, Ye, Huang & Chen, 1999)

taxonomicNotes: This species was moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus by Jiang et al. (2019).

We follow Bordoloi et al. (2007) in removing this species from the synonymy of Rhacophorus bipunctatus, where it has been placed by Inger et al. (1999), and in treating Rhacophorus namdaphaensis as a synonym of this species.

This species is a complex (Li et al. 2012, Dang et al. 2016).

This species was treated as part of Amolops chunganensis, until it was described as a separate taxon by Wu and Tian (1995). However, Fei et al. (1999) treated it as a synonym of A. chunganensis, but Ohler (2007) demonstrated its validity, and also treated Rana daorum as a synonym of this species.
Myotis siligorensis probably represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species
Two subspecies are recognized by Wilson and Reeder (2005): N. g. goral, and N. g. bedfordi.

The subspecies N.n. cetti in Sardinia (Italy), N.n. corsa in Corsica (France) and N.n. cypriaca (Cyprus) are highly differentiated and are often considered as distinct species. These insular subspecies, as well as N.n. schweizeri from Milos (Greece) and the isolated populations in North Africa are very rare. Of the nine known subspecies, three are distributed in Russia and adjacent counties: N. n. natrix (Linnaeus, 1758) on the most part of the European territory of the former USSR, except for the Trans-Volga territory, the extreme south-eastern regions and eastern Ciscaucasia; N. n. scutata (Pallas, 1771) is found in the Trans-Volga area, in the Urals, in western Siberia, Kazakhstan, in Buryatia and in the south of eastern Siberia. N. n. persa (Pallas, 1814) is known from the eastern Ciscaucasia, Transcaucasia and southwestern Turkmenistan, and by single records from the Crimea. The taxonomic distinctiveness of N. n. gotlandica seems very doubtful (R. Sindaco pers. comm., October 2008).

Yu et al. (2007) suggest that Bombina microdeladigitora and Bombina fortinuptialis be considered as subspecies of Bombina maxima given the low genetic differences among these taxa. However, we follow Frost and recognize Bombina microdeladigitora, B. fortinuptialis and B. lichuanensis as valid species.

This species has several described subspecies:
D. maculatus maculatus (Gray, 1845), found in Thailand and Malaysia;
D. maculatus haasei Boettger, 1893, found in eastern Thailand, Cambodia and Vietnam;
D. maculatus whiteheadi Boulenger, 1899, from northern Thailand, northern Vietnam and Hainan 
D. maculatus divergens Taylor 1934, found in northwestern Thailand.
The validity of these subspecies is not clear (Manthey 2008).

It is unclear what constitutes a species within Himalayan Japalura. Given current information it may be that every drainage basin has an endemic species, implying that J. tricarinata is likely to be a species complex and highlighting the need for genetic surveys of this group (J. Macey pers. comm.).

Hemidactylus frenatus was first described by Dumeril and Bibron in 1836 based on specimens from Java (Brygoo 1991). Fitzinger (1826) used the name Hemidactylus javanicus but as no description or diagnosis was provided, the nomen is considered as nomen nudum (Bauer 1994).
DNA evidence suggests that this taxon includes more than one species. However separation is cryptic.
The neotype for this species was described in 2007, and was accompanied by several paratypes (Rasmussen et al. 2007).

The genus Polyodontognathus has been described for this species (Kharin 2004). Kharin (2004) also suggests there may be two subspecies: H. c .caerulescens in the west (India, Sri Lanka, Burma, Malacca Straits) and H. c. hybridus (Sclegel 1844) in the east (Thailand, Indonesia, Australia). Data from Sanders et al. (2013) confirmed that the taxon belongs to Hydrophis.
This species has also been treated under the genus Pseudolaticauda (the subgeneric name).

This is a species complex (A. Rasmussen pers. comm. 2009). Three subspecies have been described.

Has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.
In the Australian region, most people call this species H. pacificus and they may be the same species (A. Rasmussen pers. comm. 2008). Sometimes treated under the genus Leioselasma.

The identification and distribution of Hydrophis atriceps and H. fasciatus are based on Smith´s monograph (1926), where he separated them at a subspecies level and mentioned the typical form (Hydrophis fasciatus) occurs to west of the Malay Peninsula and the other form (Hydrophis atriceps) is found east of the Malay Peninsula throughout the Malay Archipelago and south to Australia. Smith mentioned the dividing line to be in the region of Singapore, despite including a specimen from China in the western subspecies and two specimens from India and Rangoon in the eastern form. The specimen from China, included by Smith in the western form (H. f. fasciatus), is the type of Hydrophis lindsayi (Gray 1831) which antedates the name H. f. atriceps by 22 years. This indicates that if the taxa are separated into two geographically distinct forms, and this specimen was incorrectly assigned by Smith (1926) to H. f. fasciatus, the right name for the eastern population would be H. fasciatus lindsayi and not H. fasciatus atriceps. Later, Cogger et al. (1983) raised the two taxa to species level, referring the Australian specimens to H. atriceps. Ward (1996) assigned five specimens to H. atriceps from the northern Australian continental shelf. All the specimens were collected by prawn trawlers (Ward 1996).Whether the name for an Australian population of the H. fasciatus complex proves to be atriceps, fasciatus or lindsayi, we regard the species to be in Australian waters based on at least one specimen from the region of Darwin (AMR14022) and the specimens mentioned by Ward (1996). We suggest using the name H. atriceps for the Australian population of this species until further taxonomic clarification (Rasmussen et al. 2014).

This species has three subspecies: Hydrophis ornatus ornatus (Gray, 1942), Hydrophis ornatus godeffroyi Peters, 1873, and Hydrophis ornatus ocellatus Gray, 1849. The status of these subspecies is very uncertain, and the subspecies ocellatus is treated in this assessment as a separate distinct species (H. Cogger pers. comm. 2009).

H. lamberti has been incorrectly considered a synonym of H. ornatus (Smith 1926). This species has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.

Before 2006, L. saintigironsi (endemic to New Caledonia), L. guineai (endemic to southern Papua New Guinea), and L. frontalis (a dwarf species endemic to Vanuatu) were considered to be the same species as L. colubrina (Heatwole et al. 2005, Cogger and Heatwole 2006).
This species has been (incorrectly) described as a synonym of H. ornatus (Rasmussen 1989).  It has also been treated under the genus Chitulia.

A recent phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognising a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and is followed by most authors (D'Anastasi et al. 2016, Leviton et al. 2014, Lillywhite et al. 2014, Mirtschin et al. 2017, Rasmussen et al. 2014, Rezaie-Atagholipour et al. 2016, Udyawer et al. 2015, Ukuwela et al. 2014).
This species has been treated under the genus Leioselasma.

This species has also been treated under the genus Microcephalophis, however, a recent molecular phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognizing a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and are followed by most recent authors.
Smith (1926) described two subspecies: K. jerdoni jerdoni and K. jerdoni siamensis. Further studies are needed to finalize the validity of the two subspecies (Rasmussen and Anderson 1990).

There has been some discussion regarding two possible subspecies L. l. laticaudata (see Rasmussen 1989) and L. l. affinus (Anderson, 1871) (see Heatwole et al. 2005) though most authorities treat L. laticaudata as a single lineage. The Reptile Database lists a third subspecies L. l. wolfii Volsoe, 1956.

This species may represent a widespread species group rather than a single genetic entity (G. Zug pers. comm.). A specimen reported by Liang (2003) as Oligodon cyclurus may in fact be conspecific with the enigmatic Simotes trinotatus, known from a single specimen and long synonymized ("clearly" erroneously based on an examination of the specimen - David and Vogel 2012) within O. purpurascens (David and Vogel 2012).
A recent phylogenetic study found no evidence of cryptic taxa within this wide-ranging snake species (Guo et al. 2019)

Takydromus sexlineatus ocellatus is sometimes treated as a full species. Additional hidden diversity may exist within this widespread species, at least in Myanmar where at least one cryptic species is thought to exist within this complex (G. Wogan unpubl. data).
Type Species: Takydromus quadrilineatus Daudin, 1802 [= T. sexlineatus Daudin, 1802] is the type species of the genus Takydromus DAUDIN 1802.

Synonymy: Tachydromus sikkimensis GÜNTHER 1888 has been removed from the synonymy of T. sexlineatus.

There has been considerable taxonomic debate over the angular-toed or thin-toed geckos, and they have been variously assigned to Cyrtodactylus, Cyrtopodion and Tenuidactylus (Auffenberg et al. 2004). This species was referred to the genus Cyrtopodion by Auffenberg et al. (2004), following the simplified arrangement presented by Anderson (1999), and despite the assignment of this species to Altigekko by Khan (2003) Following Bauer et al. (2013) it is now treated under Altiphylax.

Gymnodactylus walli was, for a long time, considered a synonym of C. stoliczkai, until Khan (1992) provided a case to recognize G. walli as a separate species, an action subsequently supported by Auffenberg et al. (2004).

Auffenberg et al. (2004) consider Alsophylax (Altiphylax) boehmi to be a junior synonym of this species.
This species is assigned to the genus Himalayophis under the revisions by Malhotra and Thorpe (2004).

Siler et al. (2014) investigated the relationship between this species and the Philippine species complex Gekko mindorensis, with which it was previously proposed it may be synonymous. Based on the results of their morphological and molecular study, these authors concluded that the species is distinct from the majority of G. mindorensis populations as presently recognized although it represents a recent - and possibly human-mediated - colonization from Luzon.

While cautioning that the complexity of the genetic patterns obtained in their coalescent analysis precluded Siler et al. (2014) from making extensive taxonomic changes to the G. mindorensis complex without further data, they were sufficiently confident in the relationship between Luzon and Lanyu clades, and of their distinctiveness from G. mindorensis from southern Luzon, to extend the range of G. kikuchii to northern and central Luzon. While they acknowledged that this action renders G. mindorensis paraphyletic pending further research, this latter is a known species complex and they argue that their arrangement better-reflects current knowledge, especially in the context of evaluating each taxon's conservation status.
Ananjeva et al. (2006) suggest that this species may be a junior synonym of Gloydius intermedius, but this is not based on molecular evidence.

The distribution of this species (sensu stricto) is likely to be reduced considerably in the near future as current work suggests further taxonomic splitting (A. Malhotra pers. comm. August 2010). This is likely to give rise to new species with much smaller ranges and hence increased conservation concern.

This species has five subspecies:
O. monticola convictus (Stoliczka, 1870) - Indo-Malayan Mountain Pitviper
O. monticola monticola (Günther, 1864)
O. monticola makazayazaya (Takahashi, 1922) - Taiwan Mountain Pitviper
O. monticola orientalis (Schmidt, 1925) - Oriental Mountain Pitviper
O. monticola zhaokentangi Zhao, 1995 - Gaoligong Mountain Pitviper.

This species has two subspecies:
Typhlops diardi platyventris Khan, 1998
Typhlops diardi diardi Sschlegel, 1839.

Belongs to subgenus Rousettus Gray, 1821. Earlier treated as a distinct species (Ellerman and Morrison-Scott 1951) the taxon seminudus Kelaart, 1850 is considered subspecies of Rousettus leschenaultii (Desmarest, 1820) (Sinha 1970, Corbet and Hill 1992, Koopman 1993, Simmons 2005). Specimens from Tripura (northeastern India) accorded to Rousettus amplexicaudatus (Geoffroy, 1810) by Agrawal and Bhattacharyya (1977) are reassigned to Rousettus leschenaultii (Desmarest, 1820) by Rookmaaker and Bergmans (1981) (Srinivasulu et al. in press).

Earlier included under Scotoeinus Dobson, 1875 (Ellerman and Morrison-Scott 1951), the taxon emarginatus Dobson, 1871, is included under Scotomanes ornatus (Blyth, 1851) (Sinha and Chakraborty 1971, Hill 1974, Corbet and Hill 1992, Bates and Harrison 1997, Simmons 2005). The taxon imbrensis Thomas, 1921, earlier synonymized under Scotomanes ornatus (Blyth, 1851) (Das et al. 1995, Koopman 1993, Bates and Harrison 1997), is treated as subspecies (Ellerman and Morrison-Scott 1951, Corbet and Hill 1992, Simmons 2005) (Srinivasulu et al. in press).
This could represent a species complex, further morphological and genetic studies are required (C. Francis pers. comm.).

Neas and Hoffmann (1987) recognized four subspecies: B. t. bedfordi, B. t. taxicolor, B. t. tibetana, and B. t. whitei. This taxonomy seems to be accepted by both western (Grubb 2005) and Chinese scientists (Wang et al. 1997, Zheng et al. 2003). In a recent analysis of the mtDNA control region, Li et al. (2003) identified three clades that corresponded generally with the three Chinese subspecies sampled.

There has been disagreement in the current taxonomy of Naemorhedus and Capricornis (Groves and Grubb 1985, Soma et al. 1987, Groves and Shields 1996) and is in need of revision. Recent genetic evidences have supported that Capricornis swinhoei is a distinct species from Capricornis crispus (Chang 2002, Min et al. 2004).

Taxonomy of serows is not completely resolved; descriptions, range maps, and assessments of conservation status in the literature vary because sources differ on nomenclature and specific/subspecific status of the various taxa. Here, we follow the taxonomy of Wilson and Reeder, 3rd edition (2005). Thus, we recognize six species of Capricornis:

• C. crispus (Japanese Serow, restricted to Japan)
• C. milneedwardsii (Chinese Serow, but also occurring in southeast Asian countries)
• C. rubidus (Red Serow, restricted to Myanmar)
• C. sumatraensis (Sumatran Serow, in Indonesia, Malaysia and southern Thailand)
• C. swinhoei (Formosan Serow, restricted to Taiwan, Province of China)
• C. thar (Himalayan Serow, along the Himalayan range)

The genus Naemorhedus is recognized as referring to gorals. Note that this taxonomy differs from that of Wilson and Reeder, 2nd edition (1993), that of the 2007 IUCN Red List (IUCN 2007), as well as that adopted by the IUCN Caprinae Specialist Group (Shackleton 1997). Additionally, most Chinese sources consider serows in China as being N. sumatraensis (e.g., Wang 1998, Wang 2002).

While taxonomy of serow has been confusing, this assessment follows Mori et al. 2019, which recognises C. rubidus as a full species of Capricornis.


The red serow (as C .s. rubidus) was listed as Endangered (A2cd) in the 2008 IUCN Red List of Threatened Animals (IUCN, 2008). However, this assessment probably included the red form of Himalayan serow which was often attributed to this species, but it is currently included in C. sumatraensis (Duckworth and Zaw, 2008).
Rhinella marina is generally considered to be a complex of several species.

Yu et al. (2007) suggest that Bombina microdeladigitora and Bombina fortinuptialis be considered as subspecies of Bombina maxima given the low genetic differences among these taxa, and there is ongoing debate about the distinctiveness of this species, Bombina lichuanensis and B. fortinuptialis (see Pabijan et al. 2013, Fei and Ye 2016 among others). However, we follow Frost and recognize B. microdeladigitora and  B. fortinuptialis to be valid species.

The subpopulation in northwestern Yunnan is sometimes assigned to the species Duttaphrynus cyphosus (Ye 1977). It is considered here to be a synonym of Duttaphrynus himalayanus following Yang (1991) and Zhao and Adler (1993). 

This species may be a taxonomic complex (India Red List Assessment September 2020).
Bufo burmanus was synonymized with B. pageoti by Dubois and Ohler (1999). The genus Torrentophryne (Yang, Liu and Rao 1996) was synonymized with Bufo by Liu et al. (2000).
This species is thought to be a taxonomic complex (India Red List Assessment Workshop August 2020).
This species was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Hyla chinensis. Old records of H. chinensis from Viet Nam are probably attributable to this taxon (see Bourret 1942).
A number of different forms are currently included in Leptolalax pelodytoides that might prove to be taxonomically recognizable.
We will not be following the taxonomy proposed by Lyu et al. (2021), and will retain this species in Megophrys until there is more stability for the genus.
A taxonomic review of this species is needed (A. Ohler pers. comm.).
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Records of Scutiger sikkimensis from northern Myanmar refer to this species.
According to Fei et al. (1977), Scutiger alticola is synonymous with S. boulengeri.
Specimens collected in Pakistan by Annandale (1917) and assigned to Rana pleskei (= Nanorana pleskei) were allocated to Scutiger occidentalis (= Scutiger nyingchiensis) by Dubois (1978, 1987).
Records of Scutiger sikkimensis from northern Myanmar refer to S. adungensis (Dubois 1979).
It is uncertain that examples of this taxon from outside China can truly be referred to Megophrys boettgeri.
We will not be following the taxonomy proposed by Lyu et al. (2021), and will retain this species in Megophrys until there is more stability for the genus.
We will not be following the taxonomy proposed by Lyu et al. (2021), and will retain this species in Megophrys until there is more stability for the genus.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.

There is ongoing confusion regarding the taxonomic validity of this species. We follow Delorme et al. (2006) in placing this species in the genus Philautus, following their examination of the type specimen.

This species is sometimes called Megophrys lateralis (Anderson, 1908) (A. Ohler pers. comm.). Complicated nomenclatural history, and sexual dimorphism in leg proportions (Taylor 1962; but see Inger et al. 1999) might be partly at fault for records of X. longipes from Viet Nam.

There is some uncertainty as to the identification of the type specimen of this species (Shi et al. 2020).

Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Lyu et al. (2021) listed this species in Xenophrys without comment, and this work was not a revision of Megophrys. This assessment retains it in Megophrys until generic boundaries are more stable.
Subpopulations from the Nicobar Islands are possibly a distinct species (Garg et al. 2018).
This form was elevated to full species by Matsui et al. (1996).

In Myanmar this species is only known from a single record, dating from 1940 (Smith 1940). It was originally described as Amolops gerbillus but is now considered to be the same as the species recently described from China.
This species was placed in the genus Amolops by Dubois (1986).
We follow Dubois (1992) and Schleich and Kästle (2002) in considering Amolops himalayanus to be a synonym of A. formosus.
The reported occurrence in Myanmar of this species has now been attributed to Amolops bellulus.
The original name Rana gracilis (Wiegmann 1834), was already occupied by Rana gracilis (Gravenhorst 1829). This species was removed from synonymy with F. limnocharis by Dubois and Ohler (2000).
This species is very similar to Amolops viridimaculatus, an endemic of adjacent Yunnan Province, China.
This species is very similar to Amolops cremnobatus. Rana senchalensis Chanda (1986) was synonymized with this species by Dubois (2000).
This species requires taxonomic revision across its wide range (A. Ohler pers. comm. September 2020).
Taxonomic revision of this species is needed as this species may be confused with F. limnocharis. Fejervarya raja has been synonymized with this species by Kurniawan et al. (2010).
This is a species complex (A. Borzee pers. comm. September 2019).

This taxon is now believed to consist of a complex of several cryptic species. Ongoing taxonomic research in Sri Lanka has revealed that Hoplobatrachus tigerinus does not occur in this country and that animals previously assigned to H. tigerinus are misidentifications of H. crassus (K. Manemendra-Arachchi pers. comm.).

Specimens collected in Pakistan by Annandale (1917) and assigned to Rana pleskei (= Nanorana pleskei) were allocated to Scutiger occidentalis (= S. nyingchiensis) by Dubois (1978, 1987). The Kashmir specimen reported by Mertens (1969), is referable to R. vicina (= Paa vicina) (Dubois and Khan 1979). Other reports of N. pleskei in Pakistan and Kashmir are references to the above collections that have now been allocated to other species.

This species represents a complex of more than one species containing many taxa with more restricted distributions (J. Rowley, T. Nguyen, S. Phimmachak and G. Wogan pers. comm, October 2013). There might even be several species in Borneo alone (R. Inger pers. comm.). The presence of Limnonectes kuhlii in India is doubtful and requires further investigation. The record might correspond to a species of Paa (A. Ohler pers. comm.).
The genus Phrynoglossus was placed in the synonymy of Occidozyga by Inger, but without reference to the type species. This species might include Occidozyga magnapustulosus as a synonym.

Paa chayunensis is considered here to be a synonym of this species, following Zhao and Adler (1993), until the taxonomic confusion surrounding this species is resolved. There is much confusion relating to the nomenclature and taxonomy of this species. Taxonomic revision should include Nanorana mokokchungensis from India and N. maculosa chayuensis from China.
The taxonomic status of this species is not clear. It was considered a synonym of Nanorana yunnanensis by Bourret (1942).
There is some variation between the Nepalese and Indian subpopulations, which needs to be investigated as they may represent two distinct species (A. Ohler pers. comm. September 2020).

Further systematic studies of populations assigned to Rana dybowskii are needed. There are significant genetic and morphological distinctions between populations from the type territory of Rana chensinensis David, 1875 sensu stricto (Shaanxi Province of China) and the populations of the Rana chensinensis complex living further north-eastwards. The specific name Rana chensinensis David, 1875 should not be used for the frogs from the Primorye and adjacent territories; the name for these populations should be Rana dybowskii (S. Kuzmin pers comm.). Included in this account under Rana dybowskii are populations from Russia, the Korean Peninsula and Japan; it is possible that the populations of the Rana chensinensis complex from northern China are Rana dybowskii, but they are retained here in Rana chensinensis until this is confirmed.
This form is probably a complex of more than one species (A. Ohler pers. comm.). The populations in Peninsular Malaysia probably refer to an undescribed species.
The identity of this species is unclear as it was originally described from a juvenile specimen (B.L. Stuart pers. comm. February 2021).
This species is often confused with Rana chensinensis and Rana amurensis (Borkin 1985).

This form is a complex of more than one species that needs further investigation, most especially with regards to its relationship with Rana dybowskii. We follow Xie et al. (2000) in separating R. kukunoris from R. chensinensis. Included in this account are populations from China and Mongolia only (this includes the isolated Mongolian population of Dariganga Sum, Sukhbaatar Aimag). Some researchers regard the population in northeastern China to refer to Rana dybowskii, this requires further investigation.
This species may belong in another genus - either Hydrophylax or Indosylvirana - but further research is required (Oliver et al. 2015).
This species is thought to be a complex, and the population in southern China is believed to contain three distinct species (Xiong et al. 2015).
This species was elevated to full species status by Inger et al. (1999) and Fei et al. (1999).

authority: Huang, Fei & Ye in Fei and Ye, 2001

taxonomicNotes: The population in Thailand and specimens collected from Xieng Khouang Province of Lao People's Democratic Republic had previously been mistaken for Babina chapaensis (Chuaynkern et al. 2010).
This is a restricted concept of Rana longicrus following the split of the broader concept into this and R. jiemuxiensis (Yan et al. 2011).

Investigations of mitochondrial DNA suggest that subpopulations from the southern Caucasus and Central Asia might represent separate species. The taxonomy of Anatolian water frogs (including this species) is still unclear; some authors suggest that the presence of this species in Turkey cannot be established on the basis of morphometric data.

There are studies that claim that this species represents a species complex and therefore are questioning the identity of marsh frogs e.g. from western Caucasus area (Ermakov et al. 2017). Some studies suggest that parts of range of this species, at least in the Balkan peninsula, actually belong to Pelophylax kurtmuelleri (Kolenda et al. 2017).
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Odorrana huangangensis (Chen et al. 2010).
This species is sometimes included in the genus Philautus. Its taxonomy requires further study.

A taxonomic revision by Biju et al. (2020) has described a new genus, Rohanixalus, for which this is the type species. The same study has also significantly reduced the range of this species pending further taxonomic research, to low elevations (0-200 m asl) in Myanmar and Thailand, as well as new records from Middle and North Andaman Islands in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands of India.

Animals formerly assigned to Hylarana taipehensis from South Asia are now included within Hylarana tytleri following the revision by Ohler and Mallick (2002). However, this species may be a species complex (Hasan et al. 2012). Thus taxonomic revision is needed as morphometric description suggests that both species might occur in Bangladesh (Md. K. Hasan pers. comm. 2020).

This species was synonymized with Pelophylax nigromaculatus by Fei, Ye and Huang (1990), and this synonymy was accepted by Dubois (1992) and Dubois and Ohler (1996). However, Zhao and Adler (1993) still consider this to be a valid species and hence it is included here pending a definitive decision on its taxonomic status.

The subpopulation on Hainan Island might belong to an undescribed species. Ohler (2007) treated Rana megatympanum, described by Bain et al. (2003), and Rana heatwolei, described by Stuart and Bain (2005), as synonyms of this species. Rana tabaca was separated from R. megatympanum by Bain and Nguyen (2004), but was re-treated as a junior synonym by Stuart and Bain (2005) (and hence is now a synonym of Odorrana tiannensis).

This species was in the past mistaken to be Rana japonica (Ye et al. 1995). This is a restricted concept of Rana zhenaiensis following the split of the broader concept into this and Rana culaiensis (Li et al. 2008).
Subpopulations from southern Yunnan Province, China might have been incorrectly identified as this species, and may actually belong to R. parvulus (Guohua et al. 2019).
Populations from southeastern Xizang, China have been identified as Nasutixalus medogensis, and were previously confused with T. moloch (Jiang et al. 2016).
This species might be a synonym of Kurixalus verrucosus (Ohler et al. 2000).

The validity of this species has been questioned in the past and it was previously considered to be a synonym of Theloderma asperum by Yu et al. (2007, 2008). However this was disputed by Poyarkov et al. (2015) and it is now recognised as a distinct species. It is part of the Theloderma asperum species group (Poyarkov et al. 2015).
This species is in the Theloderma leprosum species group (Poyarkov et al. 2015).
The population in Thailand for this species is suspected to be a complex, but requires confirmation (S. Phimmachak pers. comm, Oct 2013).

The taxonomic identity of this species compared to Philautus gryllus, P. bisacculus and Rhacophorus verrucosus is not certain, and nor is its allocation to the genus Philautus (Bossuyt and Dubois 2001).
This form was previously thought to be conspecific with Rhacophorus dugritei (Orlov et al. 2001), but was removed from its synonymy by Li et al. (2012).

We follow Bordoloi et al. (2007) in treating Rhacophorus htunwini as a synonym of this species, and in removing Rhacophorus rhodopus from the synonymy of this species, where it had been placed by Inger et al. (1999). It is possible that populations from southern Thailand and Malaysia, currently assigned to this species, belong to an undescribed form (A. Ohler pers. comm.).
This species was included in Rhacophorus by Inger (1966), then placed in Polypedates by Liem (1970), and then returned to Rhacophorus by Dubois (1987).
Rhacophorus wui and R. hongchibaensis have been split from this species complex (Li et al. 2012). R. puerensis and R. hui are removed from synonymy as considered as valid species (Li et al. 2012).
This species might be a synonym of Rhacophorus taronensis (Wilkinson and Rao 2004).
This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
We follow Dubois (1986) in considering Polypedates himalayensis to be a subspecies of this species.
This species is commonly misidentified as Polypedates leucomystax.
This species was moved from Rhacophorus to Aquixalus by Delorme et al. (2005), and from Aquixalus to Kurixalus by Li et al. (2008).
This species was formerly treated under the genus Rhacophorus but is now placed under Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
This species was reassigned from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus by Jiang et al. (2019).
This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
It is likely that Rhacophorus gongshanensis from southwestern Yunnan Province, China, is a synonym of this species (Wilkinson and Rao 2004).
Mainland Southeast Asian records of Rhacophorus appendiculatus are referred to this taxon. Kurixalus odontotarsus might be a synonym of this species (Ohler et al. 2000).

Berman et al. 2005 removed Salamandrella schrenkii from the synonymy of S. keyserlingii. However, on the advice of S.L. Kuzmin pers. comm. we do not not follow this change here, pending a larger scale resolution of the taxonomic issues associated with this species.
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2004). It could comprise more than one species.

The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature (2003) ruled that the name for this wild species is not invalid by virtue of being antedated by the name based on the domestic form. Therefore, IUCN considers the wild species of Bactrian Camel under Camelus ferus, while the domestic form is considered under Camelus bactrianus (see Gentry et al. 2004).

Grubb (2005) lists ferus as a subspecies of bactrianus, contrary to most authors.

One-humped camels (Camelus dromedarius) and Bactrian camels (Camelus ferus) can produce viable hybrids (Camelus dromedarius hybridus J. Fischer 1829, unavailable), but hybrid males are thought to be sterile (A.P. Gray 1972).

Samples of skin taken from the remains of dead wild Bactrian Camels have been sent to scientists for genetic DNA testing. The results have been remarkable. Each skin sample has shown two or three distinct genetic differences to the domestic Bactrian camel and a 3% base difference. This answers the charge that the wild Bactrian camel is a domestic runaway.

Genetic analyses in the Atlantic and Indo-Pacific indicate that nesting populations comprise separate and identifiable stocks that should be treated as separate management units (Bass et al. 1996, Bowen et al. 1996, Bowen and Karl 2007). Hawksbill aggregations on foraging grounds comprise animals from multiple nesting populations and often include animals from distant rookeries (Broderick et al. 1994, Bowen et al. 2007).

Corbet and Hill (1992) recognized two groups on the mainland separated by degree of tail pilosity and some cranial and dental dimensions, but the significance of these differences needs to be assessed by study of larger series. Hapalomys delacouri is still represented only by a few specimens. Specimens of H. longicaudatus reported from Yunnan by Wang (2003) are probably this species. The species has been infrequently encountered by collectors, is probably restricted to a special habitat (bamboo, for example), has a patchy distribution, and will likely be found to occur over a broader range than is now indicated by extant specimens (Musser and Carleton 2005). The description of Hapalomys suntsovi from Bu Gia Map national Park (Abramov et al. 2017) casts doubt over the distribution of Hapalomys within Vietnam, further genetic and ecological work is needed to clarify the range of these two species.

This taxon was formerly considered a subspecies of S. entellus.  The other two species lania and achilles described by Elliot (1909) and Pocock (1928), respectively are considered junior synonyms of Semnopithecus schistaceus by Groves (2001), as first postulated by Napier (1985).

authority: Geissmann, Ngwe Lwin, Saw Soe Aung, Thet Naing Aung, Zin Myo Aung, Tony Htin Hla, Grindley & Momberg, 2011
taxonomicNotes:
This is a recently described species of Snub-nosed Monkey from the high altitudes of northeastern Kachin state, northeastern Myanmar. Descriptions are based on a skin and skulls of four specimens obtained from local hunters. The new species is geographically isolated from other Snub-nosed Monkeys and separated from them by two major barriers the Mekong and the Salween (Thanlwin) rivers.

It is closely related to Rhinopithecus bieti
Groves in Wilson and Reeder (1993) also treats this as a distinct species but under the genus <Pygathrix. There is now good support to keep it in Rhinopithecus see Novak (1999).
Several subspecies have been recognized (Groves 2005), although Groves (2001) treated the species as monotypic. No subspecies are evaluated here, pending a revision of the taxon.

Morphology, genetics and taxonomic variation in northeastern Indian macaques, including this taxon, is very poorly known (Sinha et al. 2006a, Chakraborty et al. 2007). Further taxonomic research is required in order to better understand its relationship to Macaca assamensis and M. thibetana.

Belongs to the fascicularis species group alongside Macaca mulatta, M. fascicularis and M. fuscata. A drop in sea level and glacial advances c.300,000 years ago is said to have brought the species’ progenitor to the island from eastern mainland of Asia. Molecular genetic studies by Jui-Hua Chu and colleagues suggest the divergence of M.cyclopsis and M.fuscata from mainland M. mulatta to be of 0.38-0.44 million years ago.

Two distinct subspecies are recognized apart from the Macaca assamensis population that is endemic to and found in Nepal, and which is likely in some way distinct (Chalise pers. comm). The two subspecies, M. a. assamensis and M. a. pelops, respectively occupy adjacent areas to the southeast and east of the range of M. assamensis.

This is member of sinica species group that includes M. sinica, M. radiata, M. thibetana. All members of sinica group are allopatric or parapatric, extending down south from Sri Lanka to eastern central China. The members of the group are characterized by a peculiar glans-penis, slender to the tip and 30 mm long. Two subspecies recognized: M. assamensis pelops and M. assamensis assamensis. Both the species differ in relative tail length of adult males. The Nepal form, different in colour and form could be a different subspecies.

This species has been revised by Fooden (2000), who regards Macaca mulatta as monotypic. The molecular differences identified among M. mulatta populations (Melnick et al. 1993; Morales and Melnick 1998; Tosi 2000; Tosi et al. 2000, 2002, 2003; Zhang and Shi 1993) are alone not consistent enough to conclusively define any subspecies.

Three subpopulation designated by molecular studies: Indian, Chinese, Indochinese (Indochinese being an introgression with M. fascicularis). Considerable hybridization with M. fascicularis in Laos, Thailand and Viet Nam and the both share an interspecific boundary of ca 2,000 km across the Indochinese peninsula in the south-east. Both M. fascicularis and M. mulatta share a range between 17°N and 14°N in Viet Nam, Laos and probably Thailand.
There is some interbreeding of released Francois’ langurs with Trachypithecus leucocephalus south and east of the River Zuo in Guangxi, China (Groves 2001).
Originally included in Trachypithecus pileatus, T. shortridgei was recognised as a separate species by Groves (2001).

This species forms a narrow area of sympatry and hybridization with H. pileatus in Khao Yai National Park, central Thailand (Brockelman 1978; Brockelman and Gittins 1984; Marshall and Brockelman 1986; Marshall and Sugardjito 1986), and with H. agilis in northern Peninsular Malaysia (W. Brockelman pers. comm.). Until at least 1925, an area of sympatry apparently existed in the region of Sriracha, about 80 km southeast of Bangkok. Therefore, a large zone of overlap in the distribution of H. lar and H. pileatus may originally have existed. In most parts of this hypothetical zone, gibbon habitat appears to have been destroyed, with the Khao Yai Park possibly representing the last remnant of the once large contact zone (Geissmann 1991). These zones demonstrate that reproductive isolation between the species is incomplete, although they do not freely interbreed in the wild where they are in contact (Brockelman and Gittins 1984).

The subspecies of Hylobates lar, although numerous and well-distributed latitudinally, are not highly distinct, in general. They are based largely on relatively minor body color variation and the degree of polychromatism of the fur (Brockelman 1985, 2004; Groves 2001; Woodruff 2005) The validity of H. l. yunnanensis as a subspecies is doubtful; it requires comparison with H. l. carpenteri (C. Groves and T. Geissmann pers. comm.). The only geographically well-separated subspecies is H. l. vestitus, which is found on Sumatra; despite its (relatively recent) isolation, however, it is not highly distinct phenotypically (W. Brockelman pers. comm.). The taxonomic status of all the H. lar subspecies, and specifically yunnanensis, requires further investigation.

This taxon is now considered monotypic; it was formerly considered conspecific with Hoolock leuconedys. The previous generic name, Bunopithecus, was changed by Mootnick and Groves (2005) to Hoolock (Haimoff et al. 1984).

Previously four subspecies were recognised (N. c. concolor, N. c. furvogaster, N. c. jingdongensis and N. c. lu) (Ma and Wang 1986), however N. c. furvogaster of south-western Yunnan, west of Mekong River and N. c. jingdonensis of west central Yunnan, China are now considered synonomous with the nominate form while N. c. lu is recognised as a valid subspecies (Thinh et al 2010a,b).

Previously, Nomascus hainanus was variously considered either a species in its own right or as a subspecies of N. concolor or N. nasutus; it is here recognized as a distinct species based on molecular, vocalization and pelage differences (Geissmann et al. 2000; Mootnick 2006; Roos and Nadler 2005; Roos et al. 2007; Thinh et al. 2010, 2011).

Nomascus nasutus has been variously considered either as a species in its own right (sometimes as conspecific with N. hainanus), or as a subspecies of N. concolor; it is here recognized as a species distinct from N. hainanus and N. concolor, based on differences in vocalizations and fur colouration as well as genetic evidence (Mootnick and Fan 2011; Van Ngoc Thinh et al. 2010, 2011; Feng et al. 2014).

Although closely related to, and for long considered to be a subspecies of Trachypithecus poliocephalus Trouessart, 1911 (see Groves 2001, 2005; Roos et al. 2007), Groves (2001) argued that it may be a distinct species, not least because of consistent differences in pelage colour patterns. Groves (2007) and Nadler (2013) considered it to be a full species (also Roos et al. 2014). Trachypithecus leucocephalus interbreeds with T. francoisi south and east of the Zuo River in Guangxi, China (Groves 2001).
