Previously placed in Arborophila but moved to Tropicoperdix following Chen et al. (2015, 2018). Former arrangement of members of T. chloropus complex (here involving also T. merlini and T. charltonii) now revised on basis of review of specimen material at NHMUK, resulting in separation at species level of forms tonkinensis and graydoni (from T. charltonii), and treatment of merlini as subspecies of T. chloropus (adopted in 2004). All subspecies recognized within this species share buffy-tan lower throat (with black spots) and black-scaled olive grey-brown upper breast, and replace each other geographically in SE Asia to form a clear group of taxa among which only narrow differences are evident. Form merlini (with closely related vivida, sometimes subsumed within merlini (Robson 2008)) was previously considered sufficiently distinctive for full species treatment on basis of its yellow legs and stronger black scaling on breast and flanks, but these differences not major (leg colour in this complex apparently variable). For characters separating T. tonkinensis, and for those confirming separation of T. charltonii and T. graydoni, see those species. Six subspecies currently recognized.

The species belongs to the Chrysopteron subgenus of Myotis, with many former subspecies and synonyms. For revision of the group see Csorba et al. (2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

Although very similar to the Thai specimens of Hebius deschauenseei, the systematic allocation of Vietnamese specimens is currently under investigation. This identification should be considered provisional (Nguyen et al. 2009).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been provisionally placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

This species was formerly placed in the genus Natrix. Smith's (1943) concept of this species ranged from northeastern India to Viet Nam, but this account follows David et al. (2007) in restricting the species to populations from northeastern India to Myanmar. Records of this species from outside this region are attributable to Hebius deschauenseei (Thailand), H. boulengeri (Viet Nam, and Guangdong and Guizhou in China), or an as-yet undescribed form from Viet Nam (P. David pers. comm. September 2011). Some records of this snake from Myanmar represent an additional, cryptic species. A revision of the H. modestum-H. venningi group is underway which will clarify the identify and distribution of true H. modestum (P. David pers. comm. September 2011).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species has been placed under Hebius (Guo et al. 2014).

This species was elevated to specific status by Das (2010) (as Amphiesma taronense, an apparently incorrect emendation), having previously been treated as a subspecies or synonym of Amphiesma venningi. Das (2010) provides no explicit justification for this action, although the accompanying description highlights morphological differences between the two taxa (particularly in the number of subcaudals). Its appropriate taxonomic status remains unclear (e.g. Uetz and Hošek 2016).

A phylogenetic analysis of the Amphiesma group has shown them to consist of three distinct, monophyletic lineages with strong support. Amphiesma is monotypic and all the remaining species are moved to Herpetoreas or Hebius. This species is not mentioned in Guo et al. (2014) although they do indicate that venningi is not monophyletic, hence as vennigi is treated under Hebius and following the Reptile Database (Uetz and Hošek 2016) we place this species under Hebius.

Gekko hokouensis as currently defined is likely to refer to an assemblage of morphologically similar but evolutionarily divergent species (Shibaike et al. 2010) that may include one or more species of conservation concern (H. Ota pers. comm. 2007).

The Marbled Cat (Pardofelis marmorata) was placed with the Asiatic Golden Cat and Borneo Bay Cat in Pardofelis by Johnson et al. (2006) representing one of the earliest felid radiations (O'Brien and Johnson 2007). Although these genetic analyses conclude the Marbled Cat is not a close relative of Neofelis, previously it had been considered so, on the basis of morphological similarities including its coat pattern, broad feet, and elongated tail and canines (Groves 1982, Corbet and Hill 1992). More recent genetic analyses (Luo et al. 2014) suggest species-level distinction between the Indochinese and Sundaic populations of the Marbled Cat although further research is needed to corroborate this.

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group. The Asiatic Golden Cat resembles the African Golden Cat, but on the basis of genetic analysis it was grouped with the Marbled Cat in Pardofelis (Johnson et al. 2006, O'Brien and Johnson 2007). However, an evaluation of skull morphology by Sicuro and Oliveira (2011) revealed that skull structure in Pardofelis is quite different to that of Catopuma. Moreover, Pardofelis has a flexible ankle joint and elongated tail as adaptations to arboreality, which are lacking in Catopuma. Based on these differences, the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group retains Asiatic Golden Cat in Catopuma.

Current scientific review of the taxonomy of wild equids (Groves 1986) places Przewalski's Horse as a subspecies of the extinct Equus ferus. Although Przewalski's Horse (Equus ferus przewalskii) can hybridize with domestic horses (Equus ferus caballus) to produce fertile offspring (Ryder et al. 1978, Trommerhausen-Smith et al. 1979), the existence of 2n = 66 chromosomes in Przewalski's Horse identifies it as being more different from its domestic relatives (2n = 64) than are any two breeds of domestic horse (Ryder 1994). Furthermore, mitochondrial DNA research has shown that the Przewalski's Horse is not the ancestor of modern domestic horses (Vilà et al. 2001). Przewalski's Horse also show a number of consistent differences in their appearance as compared to domestic horse breeds: the mane is short and erect when in good body condition; forelocks are nearly nonexistent; the upper part of the tail has short guard hairs; a dark dorsal stripe runs from the mane down the spine to the tail; several dark stripes can be present on the carpus and generally the tarsus (Groves 1994). Przewalski's Horses grow a thick mane in winter, which contrary to domestic horses they shed each spring with the rest of their winter coat.

Other studies of the genetic differences between Przewalski's and domestic horses have indicated very little genetic distinction between them. Only four alleles at four separate serological marker loci have been identified as specific to Przewalski's Horse (Bowling and Ryder 1987); the vast majority of blood protein variants are present in both Przewalski's and domestic horses and even the fastest evolving DNA region known in mammals (the mitochondrial DNA control region), does not show significant differences between the two types of horse (Ishida et al. 1995, Oakenfull and Ryder 1998). Thus it is clear that Przewalski's and domestic horses are very closely related and have in the past interbred, but the fixed chromosomal number difference between them indicates that they are distinct populations (Oakenfull et al. 2000). A variety of molecular studies support their phylogenetic relationship as sister taxa (Steiner et al. 2012, Côté et al. 2013) diverging between 150,000 and 250,000 years ago (Goto et al. 2011, Steiner and Ryder 2011).

Cuora flavomarginata is generally considered to include the form evelynae as a subspecies (Ota et al. 2009), though Ernst et al. (2008) retained evelynae as a full species. The name sinensis has been applied to mainland Chinese populations as a subspecies, with the typical flavomarginata restricted to Taiwan, but recent reviews (Fritz and Havas 2007; Ota et al. 2009; TTWG 2010) have not recognised Taiwanese and mainland populations as taxonomically distinct.

Cuora yunnanensis has been suggested to be an old example of an inter-specific hybrid, but a 1908 museum specimen was found to have unique mt-DNA indicating it to be a valid species status (Parham et al. 2004), and recent trade specimens of unreported origin agreed genetically with the 1908 specimen (He et al. 2007).

Two subspecies (Chelydra serpentina serpentina (Linnaeus, 1758) and C. s. osceola Stejneger, 1918) were recognized until osceola was synonymized with serpentina by Shaffer et al. (2008), based on lack of significant genetic differentiation. Phillips et al. (1996) removed the former subspecies rossignoni and acutirostris by elevating these to species level, based on genetic differentiation.

Previously extending to Argentina with about 15 subspecies in North, Central and South America, most former subspecies have been elevated to species rank in recent years, leaving only Trachemys scripta scripta, T.s. troostii and T.s. elegans as current subspecies (see Seidel 2002, TTWG 2007, Fritz and Havas 2007, for details).

Traditionally placed in Chinemys, reevesii has in recent years been widely accepted as a species of Mauremys (Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2010). The species includes the forms Chinemys megalocephala Fang, 1934, Geoclemys grangeri Schmidt, 1925, and Damonia unicolor Gray, 1873, which have on occasion been considered as valid species or subspecies, but have in recent years been treated consistently as synonyms of reevesii (Guo et al. 1997; Fritz and Havas 2007, TTWG 2010).
Records of this species from the central highlands of Viet Nam and Cambodia represent Liolaemus rubritaeniata, following Hartmann et al. (2012).

Nguyen et al. (2011), in a review of Dopasia in Indochina, removed Dopasia ludovici from the synonymy of D. harti. These authors provisionally elected to retain D. hainanensis as a distinct species despite noting that the diagnostic characters of the latter taxon may change with age. Further research is needed to clarify the relationships between these taxa (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).

Nguyen et al. (2011), in a review of Dopasia in Indochina, removed Dopasia ludovici from the synonymy of D. harti. These authors provisionally elected to retain D. hainanensis as a distinct species despite noting that the diagnostic characters of the latter taxon may change with age. Further research is needed to clarify the relationships between these taxa (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2017).

Dopasia ludovici was long regarded as a synonym of D. harti (Pope 1935, Smith 1935, Bourret 2009, Nguyen et al. 2009), although Brygoo (1987) suggested that it should be considered a distinct species based on the number of vertebrae from the atlas to the remnants of the hind leg bones. In a review of Indochinese Dopasia Nguyen et al. (2011) further distinguished D. ludovici from D. harti based on differences in lateral color pattern and recommended treating it as a valid species.

The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature (2003) ruled that the name for this wild species is not invalid by virtue of being antedated by the name based on the domestic form. Therefore, IUCN considers the wild species of yak under Bos mutus, while the domestic form is considered under Bos grunniens (see Gentry et al. 1996).

Grubb (2005) lists mutus as a subspecies of grunniens, contrary to most authors.

Grismer et al. (2013) proposed elevating the subspecies Hemiphyllodactylus yunnanensis dushanensis, H. y. jingpingensis and H. j. longlingensis to full species on the basis of molecular evidence that these lineages were not one another's closest relatives. Although these authors conducted no morphological analysis and there is some overlap in the characters they provide (Uetz et al. 2019), this arrangement has since been accepted by other authors working on Hemiphyllodactylus (see synonym list in Uetz et al. 2019), none of which have, however, discussed these taxa in detail. Morphological diagnosis is often difficult within this genus but the existence of a lineage endemic to eastern Yunnan (i.e. the concept of H. yunnanensis applied by Grismer et al. 2013) is consistent with known patterns of diversity in this group (A. Bauer pers. comm. 2019)  This account consequently provisionally accepts H. yunnanensis, H. dushanensis, H. jingpingensis and H. longlingensis as full species.

authority: Nguyen, Lehmann, Le Duc, Duong, Bonkowski & Ziegler, 2013

taxonomicNotes:
This species was revised by Wang et al. (1993). It is a well-defined species sharply distinct from the parapatric or marginally sympatric M. chrysogaster; see Grubb (1982).

Four subspecies are recognized by Grubb (2005):
M. b. berezovskii Flerov, 1929; Sichuan, Qinghai, Tibet
M. b. bjiangensis Wang & Li, 2003; northwestern Yunnan;
M. b. caobangis Dao, 1969; Yunnan, Guangxi, Guangdong, northern Viet Nam;
M. b. yunguiensis Wang & Ma, 1993; Yunnan-Guizhou highland, Hunan, Jiangxi; Wang (2003) lists an unnamed form as occurring in south Gansu, Ningxia, south Shaanxi, west Hubei and west Henan (Wang et al. 1993); Wemmer (1998).

Moschus anhuiensis has in the past been included in this species (Yang et al. 2003); it is still not clear whether or not the recognized subspecies are really part of this species. The subspecies M. b. caobangis is a good candidate for separate species status, but this has never been looked at (J.W. Duckworth pers. comm.). Until recently the Viet Namese population was considered to be M. moschiforus by Russian scientists (much literature follows this; J.W. Duckworth pers. comm.).
Pteruthius flaviscapis and P. aeralatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. flaviscapis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Lanius isabellinus and L. phoenicuroides (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. isabellinus following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Urocissa whiteheadi and U. xanthomelana (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as U. whiteheadi following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Nucifraga caryocatactes, N. hemispila and N. multipunctata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as N. caryocatactes following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Phylloscopus trochiloides , P. nitidus and P. plumbeitarsus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. trochiloides (see AERC TAC [2003]; Cramp et al. [1977-1994]; Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]).

Phylloscopus borealis , P. examinandus and P. xanthodryas (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. borealis following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Christidis & Boles (2008), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Aegithalos iouschistos and A. bonvaloti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. iouschistos following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Aegithalos caudatus and A. glaucogularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. caudatus following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Acrocephalus arundinaceus and A. orientalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. arundinaceus following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

A comprehensive phylogenetic analysis of bulbuls (Shakya and Sheldon 2017) recommends that the five species previously lumped as Pycnonotus melanicterus be moved into the genus Rubigula (Blyth, 1845), consequently R. melanictera, R. gularis, R. flaviventris, R. dispar and R. montis (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2019) are accepted.

Pycnonotus melanicterus, P. gularis, P. flaviventris, P. dispar and P. montis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. melanicterus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Calandrella brachydactyla and C. dukhunensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped into C. brachydactyla following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Until recently considered conspecific with C. brachydactyla, but molecular evidence places it as sister to C. acutirostris (Alström et al. 2013); this finding accepted here, and present species appears to differ in its longer wings (allow 1); deeper or shorter bill (allow 1); fulvous-washed breastband (1); heavier, darker streaking on upperparts (1); and melodious song distantly recalling Lullula arborea (Schäfer 1938) (allow 3). Monotypic.

Tarsiger cyanurus and T. rufilatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. cyanurus following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Cyornis rubeculoides and C. glaucicomans (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. rubeculoides following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Zoothera mollissima and Z. griseiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Z. mollissima following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993), which included the formerly overlooked Z. salimali (Alström et al. 2016)
Turdus poliocephalus and T. niveiceos (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. poliocephalus following Christidis & Boles (2008) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Yang and Rao (2008) elevated the former subspecies Calotes kingdonwardi bapoensis to specific status and assigned it to the genus Japalura. Subsequently, Mahony (2010) redescribed C. kingdonwardi and reassigned it to Pseudocalotes. While Mahony (2010) noted that, having not examined specimens, he had "no comment on the validity of the recent elevation of Calotes kingdonwardi bapoensis", he noted that it is "clearly" not referable to Japalura and that neither the English text in the original description nor a characterization of the C. k. bapoensis holotype by Vindum et al. (2003) was sufficient to distinguish it from P. kingdonwardi. As such he adopted a traditional taxonomy retaining this taxon as a subspecies of P. kingdonwardi pending further research to confirm its taxonomic status, and this scheme is followed here.

authority: Nguyen, Wang, Yang, Lehmann, Le, Ziegler & Bonkowski, 2013

taxonomicNotes: This species is difficult to distinguish from related species, particularly the similarly parthenogenic, triploid Hemidactylus garnotii (Darevsky et al. 1984), and karyological data is necessary to distinguish it from the common and widespread H. frenatus (B. Stuart pers. comm. 2017).

Hikida and Zhao (1989) note that one of the paratypes, the sole specimen from Hubei, differs from the other three specimens in lacking a postnasal. In the absence of any other known morphological differences these authors attribute this to intraspecific variation, but note that this character is diagnostically relevant for distinguishing species in other members of this genus.
This species was described based on two hatchlings and two embryos (Hikida 1989). As adult characters are unknown, it is possible that taxonomic issues exist with this species.

authority: Nguyen, Schmitz, Nguyen, Orlov, Böhme & Ziegler, 2011

taxonomicNotes: Groves (2011) considered that the two taxa of Ailuridae, Ailurus fulgens fulgens and A. f. styani, should be treated as two separate species.
Larvivora ruficeps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Luscinia following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Rana kunyuensis has been synonymized under this species by Zhou et al. (2015).
Sinosuthora zappeyi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Paradoxornis zappeyi.
Clanga clanga (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aquila.
Dicrurus annectens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Dicrurus annectans.
Horornis diphone (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cettia diphone.
Horornis fortipes (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cettia fortipes.
Locustella major (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Bradypterus major.

As part of their overhaul of the Locustellidae (see below) Alström et al. (2018) introduced the generic name Helopsaltes to cover the monophyletic group of Locustella warbler species ochotensis, pleskei, certhiola, pryeri, fasciolata and amnicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016). They found no morphological diagnostic characters, but identified a clear difference in voice.Has been considered conspecific with either or both of H. certhiola and H. ochotensis, but differs in voice, morphology and ecology. Molecular data reveal intraspecific structure among populations assigned to present species, while simultaneously suggesting that H. ochotensis shows remarkably little divergence (Drovetski et al. 2004, Drovetski et al. 2015). Monotypic.
Iduna caligata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hippolais caligata.

Schoeniparus brunneus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe brunnea.

Linaria flavirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Carduelis following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Himalayapsitta roseata (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) was previously listed as Psittacula roseata (del Hoyo et al. 2014). Braun et al. (2019) report the situation where the parrot genera Psittinus, Tanygnathus and Mascarinus nest genetically within Psittacula, meaning that either Psittacula replaces these latter three genera or it breaks down into monophyletic genera of their own. The latter course is preferred, building on Braun et al. (2016), where several genera were established, including Himalayapsitta for P. finschii, P. himalayana, P. roseata and P. cyanocephala.

Himalayapsitta finschii (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) was previously listed as Psittacula finschii (del Hoyo et al. 2014). Braun et al. (2019) report the situation where the parrot genera Psittinus, Tanygnathus and Mascarinus nest genetically within Psittacula, meaning that either Psittacula replaces these latter three genera or it breaks down into monophyletic genera of their own. The latter course is preferred, building on Braun et al. (2016), where several genera were established, including Himalayapsitta for P. finschii, P. himalayana, P. roseata and P. cyanocephala.

Oriolus oriolus and O. kundoo (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as O. oriolus following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Calidris subruficollis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Tryngites.

The former separation into the Western subspecies Cricetus cricetus canescens is no longer valid due to recent genetic studies (Neumann et al. 2004, 2005; Stefen 2013; Schroder et al. 2014). Several genetic lineages exist within the species (Banaszek et al. 2010; Neumann et al. 2004, 2005).
Mareca penelope (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Anas.
Phylloscopus collybita and P. tristis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. collybita following AERC TAC (2003).
Iduna rama (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hippolais rama.
Records of this species from Cambodia represent confusion with Acanthosaura cardamomensis (T. Neang pers. comm. 2017).

Carduelis carduelis and C. caniceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. carduelis following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 and supplements); Christidis and Boles (2008); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); SACC (2005 and updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Turbott (1990).
Falcipennis falcipennis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Dendragapus.

Japalura szechwanensis was synonymized within Japalura fasciata by Ota (2000). Although the name J. szechwanensis has recently been used to refer to a recognized species (Rao et al. 2017), this work did not review its taxonomic status or justify this treatment. This account consequently includes J. szechwanensis as a junior synonym of Diploderma fasciata.
Cyanopica cyanus and C. cooki (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. cyanus following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Nucifraga caryocatactes, N. hemispila and N. multipunctata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as N. caryocatactes following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Pica pica, P. mauritanica, P. asirensis and P. hudsonia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. pica following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 and supplements), Christidis and Boles (2008), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Locustella chengi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized as a species following work by Alström et al. (2015).

The genus Dryophytes was resurrected from synonymy under Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016) and this species was transferred from Hyla to Dryophytes. Dryophytes suweonensis was synonymised with this species by Dufresnes et al. (2016), but was resurrected again by Borzée et al. (2018).

This species is a member of the “Dryophytes japonicus group” (Hua et al. 2009), recently renamed from Hyla by Duellman et al. (2016), and as a clear split with the “Hyla arborea group” (sensu stricto Anderson and Green 1991). This species will be further divided into two taxa: D. japonicus and D. stepheni Boulenger, 1888 (senior synonym of H. ussuriensis Nikolskii, 1918). See Fei (1999) for further taxonomic resolution. Based on phylogenetic studies, it appears that Hyla heinsteinitzi is a name based on introduced subpopulations of Dryophytes japonicus (Stöck et al. 2008, 2010).

Following a molecular phylogeography study, this species is thought to be a complex of two or more species, one with the range of Honshu and Hokkaido, Japan, and the Russian Far East islands of Kunashir and Sakhalin, and another with the range of southwestern Japan, the Korean peninsula, Transiberian China, Russia, and Mongolia (Dufresnes et al. 2016).
Sittiparus varius, S. owstoni, S. olivaceus and S. castaneoventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Parus varius following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Sittiparus varius, S. owstoni, S. olivaceus and S. castaneoventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Parus varius following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Mirafra javanica (Christidis and Boles [2008]; Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]) and M. cantillans (Dowsett and Forbes-Watson [1993]; Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped into M. javanica following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).

As part of their overhaul of the Locustellidae (see below) Alström et al. (2018) introduced the generic name Helopsaltes to cover the monophyletic group of Locustella warbler species ochotensis, pleskei, certhiola, pryeri, fasciolata and amnicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016). They found no morphological diagnostic characters, but identified a clear difference in voice. 

Before this genus change, Locustella fasciolata and L. amnicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously treated as a single species, L. fasciolata, following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993). Monotypic.
Locustella thoracica and L. kashmirensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Bradypterus thoracicus following Round and Loskot (1995).
Alophoixus pallidus and A. griseiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. pallidus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Phylloscopus borealis , P. examinandus and P. xanthodryas (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. borealis following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 and supplements), Christidis and Boles (2008), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Sinosuthora brunnea and S. ricketti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Paradoxornis brunneus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Sinosuthora brunnea and S. ricketti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Paradoxornis brunneus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

The former subspecies Varanus salvator togianus (Peters, 1872), V. s. nuchalis, V. s. cumingi, and Varanus salvator marmoratus (WIiegmann, 1834) have been elevated to full species status (Koch et al. 2007), but Varanus salvator remains polytypic (Koch et al. 2013).
Pomatorhinus ferruginosus and P. phayrei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. ferruginosus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Garrulax cineraceus and G. cinereiceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as G. cineraceus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Garrulax chinensis and G. monachus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as G. chinensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Phylloscopus intensior (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as P. davisoni.
This is a restricted concept of this species following the split of the broader concept into this and Gracixalus sapaensis (Matsui et al. 2017).

Some populations of Ingerophrynus galeatus in central Viet Nam are believed to have been misidentified and actually belong to Ingerophrynus macrotis which needs to be confirmed (T. Nguyen pers. comm. March 2015).

Some subpopulations in central Viet Nam that have been identified as Ingerophrynus galeatus may actually belong to Ingerophrynus macrotis, although this needs to be confirmed (T. Nguyen pers. comm. March 2015).
Nanorana fansipani has been synonymized under this species by Dubois and Ohler (2005).
We follow Ohler (2003) in considering Ophryophryne poilani to be a junior synonym of O. microstoma.
We follow Ohler and Delorme (2006) in separating this species from Rhacophorus reinwardtii. Some populations of this species have previously been treated as Rhacophorus nigropalmatus.

Szczerbak (1974) suggested that Eremias quadrifrons may have been described based on an aberrant specimen of E. multiocellata. Sampling near the type locality reported by Orlova et al. (2017) obtained several specimens of E. multiocellata with patterning resembling E. quadrifrons. As the holotype remains the only confirmed record of E. quadrifrons these authors were unable to clarify its taxonomic status, and recommended further research including field surveys in order to clarify its taxonomic status and relationship to the E. multiocellata complex.
According to different views includes from three to six subspecies (Shenbrot 1991).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Specimens mapped from Nei Mongol are probably Alticola semicanus (Smith and Xie 2008).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
A. stracheyi is considered to be conspecific.
Subgenus Platycranius. Citations and synonyms are discussed by Pavlinov and Rossolimo (1987) and Gromov and Erbajeva (1995).
This species was formerly considered a subspecies of A. agraius (Smith and Xie 2008).
Requires taxonomic review (Musser and Carleton 2005).
This species was treated as a subspecies of Apodemus draco by Feng et al. (1986). Liu et al. (2004) showed that there is considerable differentiation between A. latronum and A. draco.
This taxon is often confused with A. sylvaticus.
The taxonomic status of southern Viet Nam species would benefit from further review.
Requires taxonomic revision (Musser and Carleton 2005).
The species is very similar to Niviventer langbianis, but has nails instead of claws on each big toe (Musser and Carleton 2005).
Was listed in IUCN Red Lists from 1996 to 2006 under the name Clethrionomys centralis.
Cricetulus sokolovi was elevated to species status based on chromosomal and pelage traits (Musser and Carleton 2005). It was formerly attributed to C. barabensis obscurus (Smith and Xie 2008).
Hutterer in Wilson and Reeder (1993) treats this as a synonym of C. suaveolens.
Dipus sagitta is only species in the genus Dipus.
This species was formerly included by some authors in Dremomys rufigenis (Smith and Xie 2008).
The western subspecies intermedius is taxonomically not well defined, but occurs in the part of its range where the species is declining.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Smith and Xie (2008) recognize two subspecies: 1) Eothenomys olitor hypolitor Wang and Li, 2000; west Yunnan (Yingjiang); 2) E. o. olitor (Thomas, 1911); northeast Yunnan (Zhaotong area).
It is the only species in the genus Lagurus.
Species taxonomy needs revision. Currently three subspecies are recognized: L. b. brandtii, L. b. hangaicus and L. b. aga.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

The taxonomic status of Hainan island populations uncertain (Smith and Xie 2008). Genetic data indicates that Leopoldamys edwardsi is a species complex, and taxonomic revision is required (Musser and Carleton 2005).
There are no recognized subspecies for Lepus yarkandensis (Hoffmann and Smith 2005).

UAE Taxonomic Note
The taxonomy of this species is problematic. Several subspecies have been described but are not always easily distinguished (Harrison and Bates 1991). M. l. arimalius occurs in the south-east of the Arabian Peninsula and is now regarded as a species M. arimalius, Arabian Jird. Specimens from UAE are usually referred to this form (Duckworth 1996, Drew and Tourenq 2005) but Aspinall et al. (2005) list M. lybicus.

The taxonomy of this species needs revision. Several subspecies are recognised. M. (P.) m. dahli Schidlovski, 1962 is currently listed as a subspecies, but is probably an independent species (Gromov and Erbaeva 1995).
Includes 4-5 subspecies.
Molecular evidence suggests this may be two species (Jaarola and Searle 2002).

The only representative of the subgenus Stenocranius. Complex subspecies structure with 11-15 subspecies. Taking into consideration fragmented range and morphological variation, Microtus gregalis probably represents a complex of closely related species. Taxonomic revision is necessary.
This species was previously included in M. oeconomus (Musser and Carleton 2005).
Six or seven subspecies are recognized, some of those have isolated ranges and their taxonomic status might need revision.
A small isolated population in central Myanmar is probably a distinct species (Musser and Carleton 2005).

This is likely to be a species complex (Musser and Carleton 2005). While Mus nagarum (from northeastern India) is considered a synonym of Mus cookii (Musser and Carleton 2005), and it is genetically very similar, it shows many morphological differences from the disjunct population in southeast Asia (K. Aplin pers. comm.).
This is a complex of multiple taxa (D. Lunde and K. Aplin pers. comm.).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
This species was previously included in Myospalax (Smith and Xie 2008).
This species was previously included in Myospalax (Smith and Xie 2008).
This species was formerly included in Myospalax (Smith and Xie 2008).

This species is sometimes included in N. niviventer, but that allocation is not supported by present evidence (see Musser and Carleton 2005). Specimens reported from Hainan are actually N. tenaster, and those from Taiwan are N. culturatus, which in the past was treated as a subspecies of N. confucianus (Smith and Xie 2008). There exists considerable geographic variation between populations of N. confucianus but the significance of this is still difficult to determine (Smith and Xie 2008). Deng et al. (2000) recognized ten subspecies, but one of these (lotipes) represents N. tenaster and another, culturatus, is now recognized as a valid species (Musser and Carleton 2005). Wang (2003) recognized eight subspecies from China, but the status of these needs to be reassessed, and Musser and Carleton (2005) consider them synonyms.
This is probably a species complex (G. Musser, D. Lunde and K. Aplin pers. comm.).
Niviventer langbianis was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Niviventer cremoriventer (Marshall 1977), but was shown to be a distinct species by Musser (1981).

Oshida et al. (2000) suggests that Petaurista alborufus lena (Taiwanese form) may warrant taxonomic distinction based on karyological differences from mainland forms. Chinese Petaurista from Qinghai and Gansu attributed to alborufus probably represent P. xanthotis (Smith and Xie 2008).

Petaurista petaurista possibly represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species. Until Corbet and Hill (1992) the forms here treated as Indian Giant Flying Squirrel P. philippensis were almost universally treated as conspecific with P. petaurista (e.g. Lekagul and McNeely 1977); where sympatric with P. petaurista sensu stricto (e.g. in Thailand) this sometimes resulted in the local forms of P. petaurista sensu stricto being considered part of P. alborufus (in, e.g., Lekagul and McNeely 1977). Great care is therefore needed in taking information from the non-Sundaic part of Petaurista range attributed to this species, as truly referring to it.
This species was previously included in Petaurista leucogenys, see discussion in Corbet and Hill (1992).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Tibetan Gazelle is a monotypic species without subspecies based on morphology.

Procapra gutturosa has not given rise to distinct geographic races. Specimens from the Mongolian Altai are indistinguishable from those of eastern Mongolia and hence the subspecies P. g. altaica described from Bayan-Tsagan-Gobi is not accepted (Sokolov and Lushchekina 1997).

Based on genetic analyses, true R. losea is probably only distributed in Cambodia, Viet Nam and south eastern China and Taiwan, with other distribution records corresponding to other taxa (K. Aplin pers. comm.).
Rattus nitidus possibly represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species.
This species was previously listed as Rattus sikkimensis or R. remotus, but R. andamanensis has priority over both (see Musser and Carleton 2005).
Rattus tanezumi likely represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species.

Formerly listed as Rattus turkestanicus or R. rattoides, but R. pyctoris has priority over both names (Musser and Carleton 2005). The use of celsus by Allen also represents this species (Allen 1926, 1940).
It is possible that this may represent a species complex.
This is generally considered to be a species complex, which possibly contains a number of restricted range species (K. Aplin, D. Lunde and G. Musser pers. comm.).
This may be a complex of several species (K. Aplin pers. comm.).

There is a well defined subspecies meridionalis according to morphology and genetics and this may even be a valid species. This subspecies is restricted to Calabria (southwestern Italy) and if further taxonomic work confirms this as a full species it is likely to merit listing in a threatened category (G. Amori pers. comm. 2007).
Will be transferred to family Gliridae.

Ellerman (1961) provides details about two subspecies, namely, Sicista concolor leathemi (Thomas, 1893) and Sicista concolor flavus (True, 1894) from the region. Holden (1993), however, synonymised these names.
This species was previously included as a subspecies of Spermophilus dauricus (Smith and Xie 2008).
This species was formerly included in the genus Volemys (Smith and Xie 2008).

Ruedi et al. (1994) considered suillus, maxi, dorsalis, siamensis and probably peguensis, microtinus, and tionis to be valid subspecies. Further genetic studies by Ruedi and Fumagalli (1996) suggest that siamensis, maxi and dorsalis may even be distinct species. More work is needed to resolve the taxonomy of this complex.

The species is distributed largely sympatrically in relation to Chimarrogale himalayica in northern Myanmar. The species is considered to be distinct by Jones and Mumford (1971), Corbet (1978), and Hoffmann (1987).
Smith and Xie (2008) recognize two subspecies: Chodsigoa hypsibia hypsibia (de Winton, 1899); Sichuan, Yunnan, Shaanxi, and eastern Xizang; and C. h. larvarum Thomas, 1911; Hebei.
Will be transferred to the genus Episoriculus.
Will be transferred to the genus Episoriculus.
This taxon was formerly included in Chodsigoa smithii, but it was retained as a separate species by Hoffmann (1985), with lowei and furva as tentative subspecies.
Corbet (1978) and Corbet and Hill (1991) included E. klossi in E. micrura, but see Yoshiyuki (1988). This taxon is considered here to include E. malayana, which Harrison (1974) included in micrura.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Wang (2003) recognized two subspecies: E. m. miletus and E. m. confinii, but here confinii is regarded as a synonym of Eothenomys cachinus following Smith and Xie (2008).

Previously considered a subspecies of S. erythrogenys, but recently elevated to species status (Harrison et al. 2003). Specimens in Xinjiang attributed to S. major are most likely brevicauda (Smith and Xie 2008).

A recent molecular phylogenetic study of 39 sea snake species in 15 genera recovered Hydrophis as broadly paraphyletic with respect to several other genera (Sanders et al. 2013). Instead of erecting multiple new genera, the authors recommended dismantling the mostly monotypic genera Pelamis, Enhydrina, Astrotia, Thalassophina, Acalyptophis, Kerilia, Lapemis and Disteira, and recognizing a single genus, Hydrophis, for these taxa (Sanders et al. 2013). This classification system avoids confusion and better reflects the history of recent and very rapid diversification of these snakes and are followed by most recent authors (e.g., Leviton et al. 2014, Lillywhite et al. 2014, Rasmussen et al. 2014, Ukuwela et al. 2014, D'Anastasi et al. 2016, Rezaie-Atagholipour et al. 2016, Udyawer et al. 2015, Mirtschin et al. 2017).

A distinctive new subspecies of sea snake from inner-basin waters of Golfo Dulce, Costa Rica has been described (Bessesen and Galbreath 2017). The Yellow sea snake, Hydrophis platurus ssp. xanthos Bessesen & Galbreath, 2017 is diagnosed by a notably smaller body size and nearly uniform yellow colouration, which contrasts with the black and yellow striae and tail spots or bands typical of the species (Bessesen and Galbreath 2017).

Oroanassa magnifica (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) was previously listed as Gorsachius magnificus (del Hoyo et al. 2014). 

Analysis of the Gorsachius genome reveals that White-eared Night-heron G. magnificus (del Hoyo et al. 2014) is more closely related to egrets Egretta than to Gorsachius and Nycticorax night-herons, and hence appears to need the resuscitation of the genus Oroanassa to be appropriately accommodated in the ardeid phylogeny (Zhou et al. 2016).

The morphological differences between G. magnificus and the two other members of the genus, G. goisagi and G. melanolophus, are so striking (length and shape of bill, pattern of head and neck, thickness of neck-plumage, pattern on belly, size of toes) that their congeneric status appears entirely improbable. The revival of Oroanassa is therefore accepted by BirdLife, albeit with the proviso that we have undertaken no research to check if the genus Oroanassa (Peters, 1931) takes precedence over any other genus name proposed in the past, noting that the species seems fairly similar to the South American Calherodius (Bonaparte, 1855) meaning that, if found also to be genetically fairly close, it would qualify instead to be treated as Calherodius magnificus.

As part of their overhaul of the Locustellidae (see below) Alström et al. (2018) introduced the generic name Helopsaltes to cover the monophyletic group of Locustella warbler species ochotensis, pleskei, certhiola, pryeri, fasciolata and amnicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016). They found no morphological diagnostic characters, but identified a clear difference in voice. 
Previously L. pryeri (del Hoyo & Collar 2016) was placed in Megalurus, but morphological features (bill and foot structure, length of undertail-coverts, wing formula) and molecular data place it within Helopsaltes (Alström et al. 2018). Subspecies sinensis suggested as perhaps a separate species, but although it is whitish vs pale grey from throat to belly (1), with less extensive and paler rufous flanks (2) and paler upperparts (1), the voices are near-identical. Two subspecies recognized.
Otus bakkamoena, O. semitorques, O. lettia and O. lempiji (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. bakkamoena following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Aerodramus brevirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Collocalia and split as C. brevirostris and C. rogersi following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Dinopium javanense and D. everetti (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as D. javanense following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Psittiparus ruficeps and P. bakeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Paradoxornis ruficeps following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Psittiparus ruficeps and P. bakeri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Paradoxornis ruficeps following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Prinia atrogularis, P. khasiana and P. superciliaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. atrogularis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Delichon urbicum and D. lagopodum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. urbicum following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Lanius excubitor, L. borealis and L. meridionalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. excubitor following AOU (1998 & supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Garrulus glandarius , G. bispecularis and G. leucotis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as G. glandarius following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Garrulus glandarius , G. bispecularis and G. leucotis (del Hoyo and Collar   2016) were previously lumped as G. glandarius following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley   & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Periparus ater (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus ater.
Poecile palustris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus palustris.
Poecile hypermelaenus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Parus hypermelaenus.
Ptyonoprogne rupestris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Hirundo rupestris.
Gracupica contra and G. jalla (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Sturnus contra following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Sylvia nana and S. deserti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. nana following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Phylloscopus calciatilis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized as a species following work by Alström et al. (2009).
Halcyon smyrnensis and H. gularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as H. smyrnensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Riparia riparia and R. diluta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. riparia following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993), SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Phylloscopus trochiloides, P. nitidus and P. plumbeitarsus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. trochiloides (see AERC TAC [2003]; Cramp et al. [1977–1994]; Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]).

Turdus naumanni and T. eunomus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. naumanni following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Terpsiphone paradisi, T. incei, T. affinis and T. floris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. paradisi following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Terpsiphone paradisi, T. incei, T. affinis and T. floris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. paradisi following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Turdus ruficollis and T. atrogularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. ruficollis following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977–1994), Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993), and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Hirundo tahitica and H. domicola (Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped, and subsequently split into H. tahitica and H. javanica following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).
Merops orientalis, M. viridissimus and M. cyanophrys (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as M. orientalis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Garrulus glandarius , G. bispecularis and G. leucotis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as G. glandarius following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

For many years the Red Deer complex, including European and North African Red Deer (Cervus elaphus), Tarim Red Deer and Eastern Asian and North American Wapiti (C. canadensis) were considered as one species. Several genetic studies have recently tried to clarify the taxonomy of this species complex, but their results are not always concordant.

Although Grubb (in Wilson and Reeder 2005) included canadensis in C. elaphus, sharing this conclusion with most taxonomists of 20th century, all original scientific papers published since 1995 have concluded that C. elaphus and C. canadensis are two valid species regardless of whether this conclusion was based on comparison of molecular (Kuwuyama and Ozawa 1999, Randi et al. 2001, Ludt et al. 2004, Pitra et al. 2004, Zhang and Zhang 2012, Liu et al. 2013, Lorenzini and Garofolo 2015), or ethological data (Cap et al. 2008, Frey and Riede 2013, Pereladova 2013). Based on morphological data this was suggested earlier by several authors, e.g. Lydekker (1898), Flerov (1952) and Geist (1998) and both recent reviews on cervid taxonomy are in line with this opinion (Groves and Grubb 2011, Mattioli 2011).

Recent analysis of the Cervus group (Lorenzini and Garofolo 2015, Mukesh et al. 2015, Kumar et al. 2016) have provided the first indications of another, fourth species (including Cervus nippon sensu latu). Mitochondrial complete cytochrome b and control region sequences were analysed under a Bayesian coalescent framework to derive phylogeny, with particular attention on populations from Central Asia. The resultant phylogenetic reconstruction suggested that, after excision of C. canadensis, red deer are differentiated  into two robust monophyletic clades corresponding to the western and eastern part of the range. At the species level, molecular data suggested this fourth species should be recognized as the Tarim Red Deer from Central Asia, including the populations from the Yarkand-Tarim and Bukhara regions and Indian Kashmir, which were formerly considered as subspecies of C. elaphus (C. e yarkandensis, C .e. bactrianus and C. e. hanglu, respectively).

Lorenzini and Garofolo (2015) suggest this taxon should be recognized as the Tarim Red Deer Cervus hanglu Wagner, 1844, as the name with priority over C. yarkandensis or C. bactrianus. This group forms a part of the western clade and appears to have diverged from C. elaphus during the middle Pleistocene, at a similar time as C. nippon diverged from C. canadensis. The genetic distinctiveness of the Tarim Red Deer group is supported by previous mitochondrial studies (Ludt et al. 2004, Pitra et al. 2004, Mukesh et al. 2015). Further investigations need to be conducted from additional molecular sources and nuclear coding genes as well as verification of morphology from museum specimens, before the elevation of the Tarim Red Deer to species level can be confirmed (Lorenzini and Garofalo 2015). Cervus hanglu was elevated to species level for the purpose of the IUCN Red List assessment in 2016. However, it should be noted that future clarification on genetic relatedness, especially studies with nuclear markers and a more formal morphological description, may lead to further revisions to the taxonomuy of this provisional species, as more information becomes available.

C. h. bactrianus and C. h. yarkandensis were not supported as distinct subspecies by molecular data (Lorenzini and Garofolo 2015). However, we refer to them throughout this account for ease of recognition
C. h. hanglu Wagner 1844 (N India (Kashmir))
C. h. bactrianus (W Turkestan, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan and N Afghanistan)
C. h. yarkandensis (E Turkestan (S Xinjiang, China))

authority: (Zhang, Li, Xiao, Li, Pan, Wang, Zhang & Zhou, 2017)

taxonomicNotes:
Currently, the following six subspecies of the Eurasian Lynx are proposed (von Arx et al. 2004, Breitenmoser and Breitenmoser-Würsten 2008, Kitchener et al. 2017):

- Northern Lynx L. l. lynx: northern Europe and western Siberia (Scandinavia, Finland, Belarus, Baltic states, European part of Russia, Ural, Siberia east to the Yenisei River).

- Carpathian Lynx L. l. carpathicus: Carpathian Mountains.

- Balkan Lynx L. l. balcanicus: Balkans (Albania, Macedonia, Montenegro, Kosovo).

- Caucasus Lynx L. l. dinniki: Caucasus Mountains south to Turkey, Iraq and Iran, formerly also in the Kopet-Dag, Turkmenistan.

- Turkestan Lynx L. l. isabellinus: Central Asia (Turkmenistan, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, China, India, Nepal, Bhutan).

- Siberian Lynx L. l. wrangeli: Siberia east of the Yenisei River (Russia).

Three further subspecies have been described that need further investigation and clarification:

- Altai Lynx L. l. wardi: Altai Mountains (Russia, Kazakhstan, China, Mongolia).

- Baikal Lynx L. l. kozlovi: Central Siberia, from the Yenisei River to Lake Baikal.

- Amur Lynx L. l. stroganovi: Russian Far East, Ussuri and Amur territories, North Korea, northeastern China (Manchuria).

The Qinling Mountains population is a distinctive genetic cluster and is significantly different from other mountain populations (Lü et al. 2001, Zhang, B. et al. 2007), diverging ~0.3 million years ago, corresponding with the onset of the Penultimate Glaciation (Zhao et al. 2013). Some argue that it should be considered a separate subspecies (Wan et al. 2003, 2005), although subspecies designation is controversial and not widely accepted. Nonetheless, there is greater consensus that this population should be managed as a conservation unit to retain genetic structure and any localized adaptation.

authority: Hou, Wu, Yang, Zheng, Yuan & Li, 2014

taxonomicNotes: Pachytriton xanthospilos has been removed from synonymy of this species (Wu et al. 2012).

authority: Yan, Zhao, Jiang, Hou, He, Murphy & Che, 2014
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Paramesotriton chinensis (Yuan et al. 2014). No record of P. chinensis currently exists from the same locality as P. qixilingensis (Yuan et al. 2014).

authority: Jiang, Rao, Yuan, Wang, Li, Hou, Che & Che, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Provisional placement based on statement of relationship to Theloderma albopunctatum.

This is a split from the broader concept of Tylototriton wenxianensis. The subspecies of T. wenxianensis from the north Dabie Mountains in Henan Province has been elevated to T. dabienicus according to Shen et al. 2012. Tylototriton anhuiensis was previously confused with this species, so subpopulations from Anhui Province that were previously attributed to T. dabienicus are now assigned to T. anhuiensis (Qian et al. 2017).
This is a split from the broader concept of Onychodactylus fischeri (Poyarkov et al. 2012).
This is a split from the broader concept of Paramesotriton caudopunctatus (Wang et al. 2013).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pseudohynobius flavomaculatus (Wei et al. 2009).
Removed from synonymy with Cynops cyanurus by Dubois and Raffaëlli (2012).
This species has been synonymized with Liuixalus jinxiuensis by Pham et al. (2018).

This species was removed as a synonym of Bufo burmanus by Yang and Rao (2008) where it had been placed by Yang et al. (1996) (according to Rao et al. (1998)). Frost (2019) notes that these authors either disagreed with or missed that Bufo burmanus was placed in the synonymy of Bufo pageoti by Dubois and Ohler (1999). This species was previously listed on the IUCN Red List as a synonym of Bufo pageoti (J. Luedtke pers. comm. August 2015).

authority: (Li, Liu, Chen, Wu, Murphy, Zhao, Wang & Zhang, 2012)
taxonomicNotes: This is a split from the broader concept of Rhacophorus hui (Li et al. 2012). This species has been moved from Rhacophorus to Zhangixalus (Jiang et al. 2019).
This species has been resurrected from the synonymy of Rhacophorus dennysi (Fei et al. 2009).
This is a split from the broader concept of Pachytriton changi, which has been removed from synonymy with this species (Wu et al. 2012).
Populations in the Philippines formerly attributed to this species were separated under the name Manis culionensis by Feiler (1998) and subsequently by Gaubert and Antunes (2005).

Traditionally considered to be a single species with some variation in colouration, morphological and molecular phylogenetic analyses have produced conflicting results and conclusions in recent years (Blanck et al. 2006, Spinks et al. 2009). The Vietnamese and possible Laotian populations are recognized as a separate species, Cuora cyclornata Blanck, McCord & Le 2006, with two subspecies, C. c. cyclornata Blanck, McCord & Le, 2006 and C. c. meieri Blanck, McCord & Le, 2006.

Until recently, all Indian and Pacific Ocean humpback dolphins were considered to be part of a single widespread and highly-variable species, S. chinensis, whose range extended throughout the coastal rim of the Indian Ocean to the western Pacific, from South Africa in the west to northern Australia and central China in the east (see for example, Jefferson and Karczmarski 2001).  However, there has long been a suspicion that the form with a distinctive dorsal hump and restricted to the Indian Ocean may be a distinct species – S. plumbea (see Jefferson and Van Waerebeek 2004).  In the last few years, mitochondrial (mt) DNA analyses also suggested that humpback dolphins from Australia (previously also included in the chinensis species) were highly distinct from other Indo-Pacific populations, possibly at the species level (Frere et al. 2008, 2011).

A global study of variation in the genus Sousa, combining data on skull morphology with both mtDNA and nuclear DNA data obtained throughout its range, confirmed that both S. plumbea and the Australian form were in fact distinct species (Mendez et al. 2013). A follow-up paper by Jefferson and Rosenbaum (2014) reviewed all the available taxonomic evidence and nomenclature, and proposed a formal revision of the genus’ taxonomy. In this scheme, humpback dolphins found in the Indian and Pacific oceans are split into three species: S. plumbea (Indian Ocean Humpback Dolphin), found only in the western Indian Ocean; S. chinensis (Indo-Pacific Humpback Dolphin), found in the eastern Indian Ocean and throughout Southeast Asia; and S. sahulensis (Australian Humpback Dolphin), found off northern Australia and southern New Guinea.  The Atlantic Humpback Dolphin, S. teuszii, is the fourth species in the genus, found only off West Africa.  This view has been accepted by the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (Society for Marine Mammalogy 2014).

There are still several unresolved issues in humpback dolphin taxonomy.  Humpback dolphins off Bangladesh have been assumed to correspond to S. chinensis, based on external appearance (primarily the shape of the dorsal fin, absence of a dorsal hump, and similar spotting patterns – see Smith et al. 2008), but recent mtDNA genetic evidence suggests that they do not group with either S. chinensis or S. plumbea, and may in fact be more closely related phylogenetically to S. sahulensis (Amaral et al. 2015).  Further work is needed to clarify their taxonomic status, but for this assessment they are provisionally included, with the caveat that future work may very well show them to be of a species separate from S. chinensis. In fact, the taxonomic affinities of humpback dolphins in the entire Bay of Bengal (i.e., eastern India, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, and Myanmar) need to be urgently re-examined. There is also still some uncertainty regarding the exact taxonomic status of populations observed in Mainland Malaysia and Borneo (see Minton et al. 2016).
There is extensive geographic variation below the level of the species in S. chinensis, most of it not yet properly documented, and the validity/limits of most proposed subspecies or geographic forms are not yet well known.  However, the taxonomic status of the Eastern Taiwan Strait subpopulation has recently been evaluated, and has been proposed to represent a subspecies, S. chinensis taiwanensis Wang et al. 2015. The nominotypological subspecies, S. chinensis chinensis, would then apply to all other animals in the species (Wang et al. 2015). This taxonomic change has been recognized by the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (Society for Marine Mammalogy 2016).

This is the new taxonomic concept for S. subtilis (Cserkész et al. 2016). Previously it included Sicista subtilis trizona now elevated to species level as Sicista trizona, and Sicista subtilis nordmanni now Sicista loriger. Cserkész et al. (2016) recommended that Severtzov’s Birch Mouse (Sicista severtzovi) be recognized as a subspecies of Southern Birch Mouse, S. subtilis severtzovi, not as a separate valid species as it was originally described by Ognev (1935).

Sun Bears on Borneo (Helarctos malayanus euryspilus) are sufficiently different from those on the Asian mainland and Sumatra, representing the typical form (H. m. malayanus), as to warrant subspecific differentiation (Meijaard 2004). There was one case of a wild Asiatic Black Bear (Ursus thibetanus) - Sun Bear hybrid recorded in Cambodia (Galbreath et al. 2008).

Cuora galbinifrons previously included the taxa bourreti and picturata as subspecies; the latter two were elevated to full species rank by Stuart and Parham (2004) (though see Fritz et al. 2006 for dissenting perspective) and reconfirmed as full species by Spinks et al. (2012) and accepted by TTWG (2014). Cuora serrata is generally accepted to be a hybrid between C. galbinifrons and C. mouhotii (Parham et al. 2001, Shi et al. 2005). Cuora hainanensis (Li 1958), once considered a full species, later a galbinifrons subspecies, is now viewed as so similar to C. galbinifrons as to not require a separate designation (Stuart and Parham 2004). The common name in Vietnamese is Rua hop tran vang.

Wang and Rao (2008) removed Gekko scabridus from synonymy with G. chinensis, within which it had been placed by Zhao and Adler (1993). Molecular research supports this arrangement (K. Zhou unpubl. data 2010).

At least some specimens previously identified as M. ginkgodens have been re-identified as the recently resurrected M. hotaula (Dalebout et al. 2014), which has resulted in some confusion about the distribution of both species.

Agarwal et al. (2018) redescribed Cyrtodactylus khasiensis and elevated the subspecies C. k. cayuensis to species level, as C. cayuensis based on diagnostic characters reported in the English abstract and the generally narrow distributions of Cyrtodactylus in this area. This scheme is followed here, but a more detailed comparison of these taxa is required to confirm this assignment.
Phrynocephalus nasatus was synonymized within P. axillaris by Barabanov and Ananjeva (2007).
This species has recently been elevated from a subspecies of Plestiodon chinensis (Kurita et al. 2017).
Records of Eremias beuchneri from Kyrgyzstan are now assigned to E. kokshaaliensis (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008).

Although Eremias multiocellata is a recognized species complex (Dujsebayeva et al. 2009 and refs therein), the validity of proposed subspecies has been questioned and the taxon is presently regarded as monotypic by Sindaco and Jeremčenko (2008). Other authors recognize two valid subspecies other than the nominate form: E. m. bannikowi (Szczerbak 1973); and the recent description E. m. tsaganbogdensis (Munkhbayar and Borkin 2010). A review of this species complex is in press, including the description of a new taxon from within this complex from the Dzhungarian Gobi (Orlova et al. 2017). Karyotype variation in a population from Bei Shan in China's Nei Mongol province may reflect the occurrence of a cryptic species at this locality; it is presently unclear whether this represents an undescribed form or the previously proposed subspecies E. m. kozlowi (Sindaco and Jeremčenko 2008). Dujsebayeva et al. (2009) tentatively assign records from central Tien-Shan to E. multiocellata based on comparisons with E. stummeri and E. kokshaaliensis (although the definition of this latter species is itself under review - Orlova et al. 2017), but note that the taxonomy of these subpopulations requires further investigation.

This species has historically been placed in the genus Typhlops, but has recently been moved to Indotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014, Pyron and Wallach 2014).

Two of five known specimens from Hong Kong have since been redescribed as a different species, Typhlops lazelli (Wallach and Pauwels 2004), although the remaining three specimens assigned to Ramphotyphlops albiceps from Hong Kong are considered to represent this species.
Lanius sphenocercus and L. giganteus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. sphenocercus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Dryobates minor (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Dendrocopos.
Chrysophlegma flavinucha (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Picus.
Psilopogon virens (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Megalaima.
Psilopogon faiostrictus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Megalaima as M. faiostricta.
Ramphiculus leclancheri (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Ptilinopus.
Hydrornis phayrei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pitta phayrei.
Hydrornis oatesi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pitta oatesi.
Urocissa erythroryncha (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as U. erythrorhyncha.
Lalage melaschistos (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Coracina melaschistos.
Thalasseus bernsteini (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
Corvus pectoralis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as C. torquatus.
Phylloscopus intermedius (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Seicercus affinis.
Fulvetta vinipectus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe vinipectus.
Chloris sinica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Carduelis following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Anser caerulescens (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Chen.
Antigone vipio (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Grus.
Agropsar philippensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Sturnus philippensis.
Hypsipetes amaurotis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Ixos amaurotis.
Grammatoptila striata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax striatus.
Conostoma aemodium (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Conostoma oemodium.
Alauda leucoptera (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Melanocorypha leucoptera.
Carpodacus sibiricus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Uragus following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Carpodacus subhimachalus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Pinicola and listed as P. subhimachala following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Erythrogenys gravivox (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pomatorhinus gravivox.
Erythrogenys swinhoei (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pomatorhinus swinhoei.
Burhinus oedicnemus and B. indicus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously lumped as B. oedicnemus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Alauda arvensis (AERC TAC [2003]; AOU [1998 and supplements]; Christidis and Boles [2008]; Cramp et al. [1977-1994]; Dowsett and Forbes-Watson [1993]; Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]; Turbott [1990]) and A. japonica (Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]) have been lumped into A. arvensis following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).

Calandrella brachydactyla and C. dukhunensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped into C. brachydactyla following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977–1994), Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993), and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Closely related to C. cinerea, with which often previously merged, and to C. blanfordi, C. eremica and C. acutirostris; until recently considered conspecific with C. dukhunensis (see related note). Geographical variation slight and clinal—becoming paler and greyer to E, more rufous and streaked above to W—but greatly complicated by strong influence of wear, considerable individual variation and lack of natural boundaries; described ranges of listed taxa somewhat arbitrary. We follow Donald and Alström (in prep) in treating Greater Short-toed Lark as monotypic, finding no support for the usually accepted subspecies woltersi, hungarica, hermonensis, rubiginosa, artemisiana and longipennis. Note that the breeding range does not extend so far east into Mongolia as previously thought, indeed it is unclear whether it occurs in Mongolia at all. The species is monotypic.
Calliope pectoralis and C. tschebaiewi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Luscinia and lumped as L. pectoralis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Calliope pectoralis and C. tschebaiewi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Luscinia and lumped as L. pectoralis following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Carpodacus thura and C. dubius (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. thura following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Aegithalos concinnus, A. iredalei and A. annamensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. concinnus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Aegithalos iouschistos and A. bonvaloti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. iouschistos following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Garrulax lanceolatus and G. woodi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Babax lanceolatus following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Alexandrinus krameri (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) was previously listed as Psittacula krameri (del Hoyo et al. 2014). Braun et al. (2019) report the situation where the parrot genera Psittinus, Tanygnathus and Mascarinus nest genetically within Psittacula, meaning that either Psittacula replaces these latter three genera or it breaks down into monophyletic genera of their own. The latter course is preferred, building on Braun et al. (2016), where several genera were established, including Alexandrinus for P. krameri, P. eques and P. exsul.
Spilopelia senegalensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Stigmatopelia.
Sturnia pagodarum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Sturnus pagodarum.
Spodiopsar sericeus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Sturnus sericeus.
Trochalopteron squamatum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax squamatus.
Trochalopteron affine (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax affinis.
Trochalopteron formosum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax formosus.
Sibia waldeni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Actinodura waldeni.
Schoeniparus cinereus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Alcippe cinerea.
Sinosuthora webbiana  (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Paradoxornis webbianus.
Sinosuthora alphonsiana (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Paradoxornis alphonsianus.
Suthora verreauxi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Paradoxornis verreauxi.
Onychostruthus taczanowskii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Montifringilla following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pyrgilauda ruficollis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Montifringilla following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

Linaria cannabina (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Carduelis following AERC TAC (2003); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Trichoglossus haematodus, T. forsteni, T. capistratus, T. weberi, T. rubritorquis, T. moluccanus and T. rosenbergii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as T. haematodus following Christidis and Boles (1994), and before then were split as T. haematodus and T. rubritorquis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Trochalopteron imbricatum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax imbricatus.
Stachyris roberti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Sphenocichla roberti.
Trochalopteron lineatum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Garrulax lineatus.

Oenanthe oenanthe and O. seebohmi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as O. oenanthe following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 and supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Zoothera salimali (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognised as a species following the work of Alström et al. (2016).
Sitta europaea and S. arctica (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. europaea following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977–1994), and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Troglodytes troglodytes, T. pacificus and T. hiemalis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. troglodytes following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 and supplements), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993), and Stotz et al. (1996).

Turdus merula, T. simillimus, T. maximus and T. mandarinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. merula following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Christidis & Boles (2008), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Turbott (1990).

Turdus merula, T. simillimus, T. maximus and T. mandarinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. merula following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 & supplements), Christidis & Boles (2008), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Turbott (1990).

Turdus ruficollis and T. atrogularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. ruficollis following AERC TAC (2003), Cramp et al. (1977-1994), Dowsett & Forbes-Watson (1993) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).

The BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group is aware that phylogenetic analyses have been published which have proposed generic rearrangements which may affect this species, but prefers to wait until work by other taxonomists reveals how these changes affect the entire groups involved.

Hydrobates leucorhous has been split into H. leucorhous, H. socorroensis and H. cheimomnestes (which see) (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018), based on the proposal of Howell (2012).
Saundersilarus saundersi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Larus.
Hydrocoloeus minutus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Larus.
Thalasseus bengalensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
Thalasseus bergii (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.

The BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group is aware that phylogenetic analyses have been published which have proposed generic rearrangements which may affect this species, but prefers to wait until work by other taxonomists reveals how these changes affect the entire groups involved.

F. g. audoboni, recognised in del Hoyo and Collar (2014), is here synonymised with F. g. glacialis following the observation that the difference is based upon a cline and that there is no genetic evidence whatsoever to indicate a distinction (Kerr and Dove 2013).
Ardenna pacifica (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus as P. pacificus.
